llm_translation: The sages taught: "Mivta" - an oath. "Issar" - an oath. Issur Issar: If you say "Issar" - an oath, you are liable; but if not, you are exempt. "If you say 'Issar is an oath'?! But didn't you say: Issar is an oath!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הָכִי קָאָמַר, ״מִבְטָא״ – שְׁבוּעָה. ״אִיסָּר״ – מִיתְּפֵיס בִּשְׁבוּעָה. אִיסּוּר אִיסָּר – אִם אַתָּה אוֹמֵר: מִיתְּפֵיס בִּשְׁבוּעָה כְּמוֹצִיא שְׁבוּעָה מִפִּיו דָּמֵי, חַיָּיב; וְאִם לָאו, פָּטוּר.
human_translation: Abaye said: This is saying: “Clear utterance” an oath, “bond” is association with an oath. prohibition “bond”? If you say an association with an oath is like expressing an oath with his mouth liable But if not exempt.
llm_translation: Abaye said: Thus he said, "Mivta" - an oath. "Issar" - is considered as an oath. Issur Issar - if you say: it is considered as an oath like one who brings forth an oath from his mouth, he is liable; and if not, he is exempt.

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי דְּמִבְטָא שְׁבוּעָה – דִּכְתִיב: ״אוֹ נֶפֶשׁ כִּי תִשָּׁבַע לְבַטֵּא בִשְׂפָתַיִם״; אִיסָּר נָמֵי – דִּכְתִיב: ״כׇּל נֵדֶר וְכׇל שְׁבֻעַת אִסָּר״;
human_translation: From where “clear utterance” is an oath? as it is written: “Or if anyone take an oath to clearly utter with his lips” “bond” also as it is written: “Every vow, and every oath of a bond
llm_translation: From where do we derive the concept of an oath? - As it is written: "Or if a soul swears, pronouncing with his lips" (Numbers 30:3). And from where do we derive the concept of a vow? - As it is written: "Every vow and every binding oath" (Numbers 30:3).

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מִמַּאי דְּאִיסָּר מִיתְּפֵס בִּשְׁבוּעָה הוּא? דִּכְתִיב: ״אוֹ אָסְרָה אִסָּר עַל נַפְשָׁהּ בִּשְׁבֻעָה״.
human_translation: Rather, from where that a bond is association with an oath? as it is written: “Or bound her soul by a bond with an oath”
llm_translation: Rather, from what does one who forbids become obligated in a week? For it is written: "Or if she has bound herself by an oath to prohibit herself."

hebrew_text: מְבַטֵּא נָמֵי – הָכְתִיב: ״לְכֹל אֲשֶׁר יְבַטֵּא הָאָדָם בִּשְׁבֻעָה״!
human_translation: “clear utterance” also it is written: “Whatsoever it be that a man shall utter clearly with an oath”
llm_translation: Expresses Nami - It is written: "for all that a man expresses in an oath"!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מִבְטָא שְׁבוּעָה מֵהָכָא: ״וְאִם הָיוֹ תִהְיֶה לְאִישׁ וּנְדָרֶיהָ עָלֶיהָ, אוֹ מִבְטָא שְׂפָתֶיהָ אֲשֶׁר אָסְרָה עַל נַפְשָׁהּ״ – וְאִילּוּ שְׁבוּעָה לָא קָאָמַר; בְּמַאי אָסְרָה עַצְמָהּ? בְּמִבְטָא.
human_translation: Rather, Abaye said: “clear utterance” an oath from here: “And if she be married to a husband, while her vows are upon her, or the clear utterance of her lips, with which she has bound her soul” While does not state: Oath. With what does she impose a prohibition upon herself? with “clear utterance,”
llm_translation: Rather, Abaye said: The expression of an oath is derived from here: "And if she shall be to a man, and her vows shall be upon her, or the utterance of her lips wherewith she hath bound her soul" - and it is not speaking of an oath; with what did she bind herself? With an expression.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם אֵימָא לָךְ, מִיתְּפֵיס בִּשְׁבוּעָה לָאו כְּמוֹצִיא שְׁבוּעָה מִפִּיו דָּמֵי; וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: ״מִבְטָא״ – שְׁבוּעָה. ״אִיסָּר״ – נָמֵי שְׁבוּעָה. אִסָּרֵיהּ דְּאִיסָּר – הִטִּילוֹ הַכָּתוּב בֵּין נֶדֶר לִשְׁבוּעָה; הוֹצִיאוֹ בִּלְשׁוֹן נֶדֶר – נֶדֶר, בִּלְשׁוֹן שְׁבוּעָה – שְׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: Rava said: Actually, I will say to you association with an oath is not like expressing an oath with one’s mouth, and this is saying: “Clear utterance” an oath. “Bond” also an oath, The verse placed the prohibition of a bond between a vow and an oath. expressed with the language of a vow, a vow. with the language of an oath, an oath.
llm_translation: Rava said: Always say to you, one who takes an oath in a week is not like one who utters an oath from his mouth; and thus he said: "Mivta" - an oath. "Issar" - also an oath. Its prohibitions of an oath - the Scripture placed it between a vow and an oath; if he expressed it in the language of a vow - it is a vow, in the language of an oath - it is an oath.

hebrew_text: הֵיכָן הִטִּילוֹ? ״וְאִם בֵּית אִישָׁהּ נָדָרָה אוֹ אָסְרָה אִסָּר עַל נַפְשָׁהּ בִּשְׁבֻעָה וְגוֹ׳״
human_translation: Where did place “And if she vowed in her husband’s house or bound her soul by a bond with an oath”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Where did he place it? "And if in her husband's house she vowed or prohibited herself with a prohibition upon her soul by an oath, etc."

hebrew_text: וְאָזְדוּ לְטַעְמַיְיהוּ; דְּאִיתְּמַר: מַתְפִּיס בִּשְׁבוּעָה – אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: כְּמוֹצִיא שְׁבוּעָה מִפִּיו דָּמֵי, וְרָבָא אָמַר: לָאו כְּמוֹצִיא שְׁבוּעָה מִפִּיו דָּמֵי.
human_translation: follow their reasoning, as it was stated: associates with an oath, Abaye says: is like expressing an oath with his mouth, and Rava says: It is not like expressing an oath with his mouth.
llm_translation: And they went according to their reasons; for it was said: "He who imposes a vow for a week" - Abbaye said: It is like bringing forth a week from his mouth, and Rava said: It is not like bringing forth a week from his mouth.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: אֵיזֶה אִיסָּר הָאָמוּר בַּתּוֹרָה? הָאוֹמֵר: ״הֲרֵי עָלַי שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל בָּשָׂר וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה יַיִן״ כַּיּוֹם שֶׁמֵּת בּוֹ אָבִיו, כַּיּוֹם שֶׁמֵּת בּוֹ פְּלוֹנִי, כְּיוֹם שֶׁנֶּהֱרַג בּוֹ גְּדַלְיָה בֶּן אֲחִיקָם, כַּיּוֹם שֶׁרָאָה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם בְּחוּרְבָּנָהּ – אָסוּר. וְאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: וְהוּא שֶׁנָּדוּר וּבָא מֵאוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם.
human_translation: The Gemara raises an objection What is the bond mentioned in the Torah? one who says: It upon me that I will not eat meat and that I will not drink wine like the day that his, father died, Like the day that so-and-so died, Like the day that Gedaliah ben Ahikam was killed, Like the day which he saw Jerusalem in its destruction. prohibited And Shmuel says: is when he is prohibited by vow since that day,
llm_translation: Challenger: What is the prohibition mentioned in the Torah? One who says, "I hereby take upon myself not to eat meat and not to drink wine," like the day his father dies, like the day Ploni dies, like the day Gedaliah son of Ahikam was killed, like the day Jerusalem was seen in its destruction - it is forbidden. And Samuel said: This is if he made a vow and it comes from that day.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְאַבָּיֵי, מִדְּמַתְפִּיס בְּנֶדֶר – נֶדֶר, מַתְפִּיס בִּשְׁבוּעָה – שְׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: Granted, according to Abaye, from that one associates with vow a vow, one associates with oath an oath.
llm_translation: In truth, according to Abbaye, from "matfis" in a vow - vow, "matfis" in an oath - oath.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְרָבָא קַשְׁיָא!
human_translation: But according to Rava’s a difficulty,
llm_translation: Rather, to Rava it is difficult!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רָבָא, תָּרֵיץ וְאֵימָא הָכִי: אֵיזֶהוּ אִיסַּר נֶדֶר הָאָמוּר בַּתּוֹרָה? הָאוֹמֵר: ״הֲרֵי עָלַי שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל בָּשָׂר וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה יַיִן״ כַּיּוֹם שֶׁמֵּת בּוֹ אָבִיו, כַּיּוֹם שֶׁנֶּהֱרַג בּוֹ פְּלוֹנִי. וְאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: וְהוּא שֶׁנָּדוּר וּבָא מֵאוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם.
human_translation: Rava say to you: Resolve and say this: Which is the bond a vow mentioned in the Torah? one who says: It upon me that I will not eat meat and that I will not drink wine like the day that his, father died, Like the day that so-and-so was killed. And Shmuel says: is when he is prohibited by vow since that day,
llm_translation: Rava said to you: Resolve it and say thus: Which is a vow of prohibition that is stated in the Torah? One who says, "Behold upon me that I will not eat meat and I will not drink wine," like the day his father died, like the day Ploni was killed. And Shmuel said: And this is when he made a vow and it came from that day.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? אָמַר קְרָא: ״אִישׁ כִּי יִדֹּר נֶדֶר לַה׳״ – עַד שֶׁיִּדּוֹר בְּדָבָר הַנָּדוּר.
human_translation: What is the reason The verse states: “When a man vows a vow to the Lord” unless he vows by an item by a vow.
llm_translation: What is the reason? The verse says: "When a man makes a vow to the Lord" - until he vows in the matter of the vow.

hebrew_text: כַּיּוֹם שֶׁמֵּת בּוֹ אָבִיו. פְּשִׁיטָא! כְּיוֹם שֶׁנֶּהֱרַג בּוֹ גְּדַלְיָה בֶּן אֲחִיקָם אִיצְטְרִיךְ לֵיהּ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: כֵּיוָן דְּכִי לָא נָדַר נָמֵי אָסוּר – כִּי נָדַר נָמֵי לָא הָוְיָא עֲלֵיהּ אִיסּוּר, וְהַאי לָאו מִיתְּפֵיס בְּנֶדֶר הוּא; קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: like the day that his father died. obvious was necessary Like the day that Gedaliah ben Ahikam was killed. may enter your mind to say: Since, if he did not vow they would be prohibited to him anyway, when he did vow prohibition would not take effect on him, and that not be associated with a vow, teaches us
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Just as on the day his father died. It is obvious! Just as on the day Gedaliah son of Ahikam was killed, it was necessary for him. Your mind might say: Since when one does not make a vow, it is forbidden - for one who does not make a vow, there is no prohibition upon him, and this is not considered a vow; this is what he is teaching us.

hebrew_text: וְאַף רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סָבַר לַהּ לְהָא דְּרָבָא; דְּכִי אֲתָא רָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: ״מִבְטָא לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״, ״אִיסָּר לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ – שְׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan also holds in accordance with this of Rava as when Ravin came Rabbi Yoḥanan says: clear utterance I will not eat of yours, bond I will not eat of yours, an oath.
llm_translation: And even Rabbi Yochanan also holds like Rava; for when Ravin came, Rabbi Yochanan said: "I cannot eat your pronunciation," "I cannot eat your prohibition" - an oath.

hebrew_text: כִּי אֲתָא רַב דִּימִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: ״אוֹכַל״ וְ״לֹא אוֹכַל״ – שֶׁקֶר, וְאַזְהַרְתֵּיהּ מֵהָכָא: ״לָא תִשָּׁבְעוּ בִשְׁמִי לַשָּׁקֶר״. ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ – שָׁוְא, וְאַזְהַרְתֵּיהּ מֵהָכָא: ״לֹא תִשָּׂא אֶת שֵׁם ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ לַשָּׁוְא״.
human_translation: When Rav Dimi came Rabbi Yoḥanan says: I will eat, or: I will not eat, a false And its prohibition from here: you shall not take an oath by My name falsely, I ate, or: I did not eat, in vain, and its prohibition from here: “You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain;
llm_translation: When Rav Dimi came, Rabbi Yochanan said: "Eating" and "not eating" - is a lie, and I warn you from here: "You shall not swear falsely by My name." "I have eaten" and "I have not eaten" - is in vain, and I warn you from here: "You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain."

hebrew_text: קוּנָּמוֹת – עוֹבֵר בְּ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: like an offering [ konamot ], violates he shall not break his word;
llm_translation: Kunamot - over in "Lo yachel devaro".

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: שָׁוְא וְשֶׁקֶר אֶחָד הֵן. מַאי, לָאו מִדְּשָׁוְא לְשֶׁעָבַר – אַף שֶׁקֶר נָמֵי לְשֶׁעָבַר? אַלְמָא ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ שֶׁקֶר הוּא!
human_translation: raises an objection in vain and a false are one. What, is not that in vain to the past, a false also to the past? Apparently, I ate, I did not eat, are false
llm_translation: Challenger: "Falsehood and lying are one." What, is it not from falsehood to transgression - also lying is from falsehood to transgression? Therefore, "I have eaten" and "I have not eaten" is a lie!

hebrew_text: מִידֵּי אִירְיָא?! הָא כִּדְאִיתָא, וְהָא כִּדְאִיתָא. וּמַאי ״דָּבָר אֶחָד הֵן״? דִּבְדִיבּוּר אֶחָד נֶאֶמְרוּ, כִּדְתַנְיָא: ״זָכוֹר״ וְ״שָׁמוֹר״ בְּדִיבּוּר אֶחָד נֶאֶמְרוּ – מַה שֶּׁאֵין יָכוֹל הַפֶּה לְדַבֵּר, וּמָה שֶׁאֵין הָאוֹזֶן יָכוֹל לִשְׁמוֹעַ.
human_translation: Are the cases comparable? This as it is and that as it is. What, they are one? that were spoken in a single utterance like that is taught “Remember and: “Observe were spoken in one utterance, that the mouth cannot say and that the ear cannot hear.
llm_translation: From the city of Irya?! This one as it was stated, and this one as it was stated. And what is "they are one thing"? That they were spoken in one utterance, as it was taught: "Remember" and "observe" were spoken in one utterance - that which the mouth cannot speak, and that which the ear cannot hear.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא הָתָם בְּדִיבּוּר אֶחָד נֶאֶמְרוּ, כִּדְרַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה – דְּאָמַר רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה: נָשִׁים חַיָּיבוֹת בְּקִידּוּשׁ הַיּוֹם דְּבַר תּוֹרָה, דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״זָכוֹר״ וְ״שָׁמוֹר״ – כׇּל שֶׁיֶּשְׁנוֹ בִּשְׁמִירָה יֶשְׁנוֹ בִּזְכִירָה, וְהָנֵי נְשֵׁי הוֹאִיל וְאִיתַנְהוּ בִּשְׁמִירָה אִיתַנְהוּ נָמֵי בִּזְכִירָה. אֶלָּא הָכָא לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ?
human_translation: Granted, there, were spoken in a single utterance that Rav Adda bar Ahava as Rav Adda bar Ahava says: Women are obligated to kiddush the day, by Torah law, since the verses state: “Remember,” and: “Observe,” anyone who is to observe, is to remember, And these women, since they are to observe, they also are to remember. But here, for what halakha is it necessary
llm_translation: In peace, there, with one expression it was stated, as Rav Adda bar Ahava said - for Rav Adda bar Ahava said: Women are obligated in the sanctification of the day through a matter of Torah, as the verse states "Remember" and "Observe" - anyone who is engaged in observance is engaged in mention, and these women, since they are engaged in observance, they are also engaged in mention. Rather, here, what is the halakha that is required of it?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא כְּשֵׁם שֶׁלּוֹקֶה עַל שָׁוְא, כָּךְ לוֹקֶה נָמֵי עַל שֶׁקֶר.
human_translation: Rather, just as is flogged for in vain, so also flogged for a false
llm_translation: Rather, just as one is punished for a false measure, so too is one punished for falsehood.

hebrew_text: כְּלַפֵּי לְיָיא? אֶלָּא אֵימָא: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁלּוֹקֶה עַל שֶׁקֶר, כָּךְ לוֹקֶה נָמֵי עַל שָׁוְא.
human_translation: Isn’t it the opposite [ kelapei layya ]? Rather, say Just as is flogged for false so also flogged for in vain.
llm_translation: According to the opinion of Rabbi Yehudah HaNasi? Rather say: Just as one is punished for falsehood, so too is one punished for vanity.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא – הַאי לָאו וְהַאי לָאו! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא כְּדַאֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי: ״לֹא יִנָּקֶה״ כְּלָל;
human_translation: obvious? This is a prohibition and that is a prohibition, Lest you say as Rav Pappa said to Abaye, will not absolve of guilt at all,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Peshita - hai lav vehai lav! Mahu d'teima ked'ammar lei Rav Papa le'Abaye: "Lo yinnakeh" klal; English translation: Simple - this not and this not! What is the reasoning? Like Rav Papa said to Abaye: "He shall not be acquitted" in general;

hebrew_text: קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כִּדְשַׁנִּי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: teaches us as answers him
llm_translation: It is being heard to us as it was taught to him.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁמֵּבִיא קׇרְבָּן עַל שֶׁקֶר, כָּךְ מֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן עַל שָׁוְא; וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הִיא, דִּמְחַיֵּיב לְשֶׁעָבַר כִּלְהַבָּא.
human_translation: And if you wish, say Just as one brings an offering for a false so one brings an offering for in vain. And this Rabbi Akiva, who deems liable to the past, as to the future.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: Just as one brings a sacrifice for falsehood, so too one brings a sacrifice for vanity; and Rabbi Akiva is the one who obligates for past transgressions.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: אֵי זוֹ הִיא שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא – נִשְׁבָּע לְשַׁנּוֹת אֶת הַיָּדוּעַ לְאָדָם. שְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר – נִשְׁבָּע לְהַחְלִיף! אֵימָא נִשְׁבָּע וּמַחְלִיף.
human_translation: raises an objection Which is an oath in vain? one takes an oath to deny that which is known to people a false oath takes an oath contradicts Say, takes an oath and contradicts
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: Meitivi: Ei zo hi shevu'at shavua - nishba leshanot et hayadua le'adam. Shevu'at sheker - nishba lehachlif! Eima nishba u'machlif. English translation: It was asked: What is an oath of falsehood? - One swears to change what is known to a person. An oath of falsehood - one swears to switch! Perhaps one swears and switches.

hebrew_text: כִּי אֲתָא רָבִין, אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה, אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ – שֶׁקֶר, וְאַזְהַרְתֵּיהּ מִ״לֹּא תִשָּׁבְעוּ בִשְׁמִי לַשָּׁקֶר״. ״אוֹכַל״ וְ״לֹא אוֹכַל״ – עוֹבֵר בְּ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״. וְאִי זוֹ הִיא שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא? נִשְׁבָּע לְשַׁנּוֹת אֶת הַיָּדוּעַ לְאָדָם.
human_translation: When Ravin came Rabbi Yirmeya says Rabbi Abbahu says Rabbi Yoḥanan says: I ate, I did not eat, a false And its prohibition from: you shall not take an oath by My name falsely, I will eat, or: I will not eat, violates he shall not break his word” And which an oath in vain? takes an oath to deny that which is known to people
llm_translation: When Rabbin came, Rabbi Yirmeya said, Rabbi Abahu said, Rabbi Yochanan said: "I ate" and "I did not eat" - this is a lie, and I warned from "Do not swear falsely in My name." "I will eat" and "I will not eat" - one transgresses by "not profaning his word." And what is a false oath? Swearing to change what is known to another person.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הָא דְּרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ – לָאו בְּפֵירוּשׁ אִיתְּמַר, אֶלָּא מִכְּלָלָא אִיתְּמַר; דְּאָמַר רַב אִידִי בַּר אָבִין: אָמַר רַב עַמְרָם, אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי: כֹּל לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה – לָאו שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה לוֹקִין עָלָיו, וְשֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה אֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו; חוּץ מִנִּשְׁבָּע וּמֵימֵר וּמְקַלֵּל אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ בַּשֵּׁם.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: This of Rabbi Abbahu, was not stated explicitly rather, it was stated by inference. that Rav Idi bar Avin says Rav Amram says Rav Yitzḥak says Rabbi Yoḥanan says Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: any prohibition in the Torah, prohibition that involves an action, one is flogged for it. But that does not involve an action, is not flogged takes an oath, and substitutes and another using the Name
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: This that Rabbi Avahu said - it was not stated explicitly, rather it was inferred; for Rav Idi bar Avin said: Rav Amram said, Rav Yitzchak said, Rabbi Yochanan said, Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Yosei the Galilean: Any prohibition in the Torah that does not involve a physical action, one is not liable for violating it, and if it does involve a physical action, one is liable; except for one who swears falsely, or one who incites others to swear falsely, or one who curses his fellow using the name of God.

hebrew_text: נִשְׁבָּע מְנָלַן? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַאי, אָמַר קְרָא: ״לֹא תִשָּׂא אֶת שֵׁם ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ לַשָּׁוְא כִּי לֹא יְנַקֶּה״ – בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מַעְלָה אֵין מְנַקִּין אוֹתוֹ, אֲבָל בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מַטָּה מַלְקִין אוֹתוֹ וּמְנַקִּין אוֹתוֹ.
human_translation: From where do we takes an oath Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai: The verse states: “You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain; for will not absolve of guilt heavenly court does not absolve him; but the earthly court flogs him, and absolves him of guilt.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Nishba menalan?" Amar Rabbi Yochanan mishum Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai, amar kra: "Lo tisa et shem Hashem Elohecha lashav ki lo yenakeh" - Beit Din shel Ma'alah ein menakin oto, aval Beit Din shel Mattah malkin oto u'menakin oto. English translation: "From where do we learn that one who swears falsely is not acquitted? Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai, as it is stated: 'You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain, for the Lord will not hold him guiltless' - The heavenly court does not acquit him, but the earthly court lashes him and acquits him."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי: דִּלְמָא הָכִי קָאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: ״לֹא יְנַקֶּה״ כְּלָל? אִי כְּתִיב ״כִּי לֹא יְנַקֶּה״ – כִּדְקָאָמְרַתְּ; הַשְׁתָּא דִּכְתִיב ״כִּי לֹא יְנַקֶּה ה׳״ – ה׳ הוּא דְּאֵינוֹ מְנַקֶּה, אֲבָל בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מַטָּה מַלְקִין אוֹתוֹ וּמְנַקִּין אוֹתוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said to Abaye: Perhaps this the Merciful One is saying: He will not be absolved of guilt at all. If it were written: For he will not be absolved of guilt, as you say. Now that it is written: “For the Lord will not absolve of guilt,” it is the Lord Who will not absolve but the earthly court flogs him, and absolves him of guilt.
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Papa to Abbaye: Perhaps this is what the Merciful One is saying: "He shall not be cleared" in general? If it were written "for he shall not be cleared" - as you said; now that it is written "for he shall not be cleared by the Lord" - it is the Lord who does not clear, but the lower court lashes him and clears him.

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא, שְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר מְנָלַן? רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דִּידֵיהּ אָמַר: ״לַשָּׁוְא״ ״לַשָּׁוְא״ שְׁתֵּי פְּעָמִים; אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לִשְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לִשְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר.
human_translation: We found an oath in vain, From where do we a false oath? Rabbi Yoḥanan himself said: “In vain…in vain,” twice. If is not matter of an oath in vain, apply it matter of a false oath.
llm_translation: I have found an oath of falsehood, from where do we know an oath of falsehood? Rabbi Yochanan said: "To falsehood," "To falsehood" twice; if it is not a matter for an oath of falsehood, give it the status of an oath of lies.

hebrew_text: וְהָוֵי בַּהּ רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: הַאי שְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל – לָאו שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה הוּא! וְאֶלָּא דְּאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאוֹכַל״, וְלֹא אָכַל – הַאי מִי לוֹקֶה?! וְהָא אִיתְּמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאוֹכַל כִּכָּר זוֹ הַיּוֹם״, וְעָבַר הַיּוֹם וְלֹא אֲכָלָהּ – רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה!
human_translation: And Rabbi Abbahu discusses this: this false oath what are the circumstances If we say oath I will not eat, and ate, that is a prohibition that involves an action. And rather that he says: oath I will eat, and he does not eat, is that flogged? But wasn’t stated oath I will eat this loaf today, and the day passed and he did not eat it, Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish both say he is not flogged?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And be in it Rabbi Avahu: How is the false oath of a week comparable? Perhaps "an oath not to eat," and he ate - is there not an action in it! Rather, say "an oath to eat," and he did not eat - who is punished?! And this was stated: "An oath to eat a loaf today," and the day passed and he did not eat it - Rabbi Yochanan and Resh Lakish both said: He is not punished!

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה – מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה לָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה, וְכׇל לָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה אֵין לוֹקִין עָלָיו. וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה – מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה הַתְרָאַת סָפֵק, וְהַתְרָאַת סָפֵק לֹא שְׁמָהּ הַתְרָאָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan says he is not flogged because it is a prohibition that does not involve an action, and any prohibition that does not involve an action, one is not flogged for it. And Reish Lakish says he is not flogged because an uncertain forewarning, and an uncertain forewarning is not considered a forewarning
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: He is not liable - because it is a negative commandment that does not involve an action, and for every negative commandment that does not involve an action, one is not liable. And Reish Lakish said: He is not liable - because it is a warning of doubt, and a warning of doubt is not considered a warning.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: תְּהֵא בְּ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״. וּמַאי שְׁנָא? אָמַר רָבָא: בְּפֵירוּשׁ רִיבְּתָה תּוֹרָה שְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר דּוֹמָה לְשָׁוְא, מָה שָׁוְא לְשֶׁעָבַר, אַף שֶׁקֶר נָמֵי לְשֶׁעָבַר.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu says: will be where I ate, or: I did not eat. What is different Rava said: The Torah explicitly extended a false oath is similar to an oath in vain. Just as in vain to the past, so too, a false to the past.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Avahu said: Let it be in "I have eaten" and "I have not eaten." And what is the difference? Rava said: In the explanation of the Torah's oath of falsehood, a false oath is similar to emptiness. Just as emptiness for the past, so too falsehood is also for the past.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה לְרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל כִּכָּר זוֹ״, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכְלֶנָּה״, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכְלֶנָּה״, וַאֲכָלָהּ – אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. זוֹ הִיא שְׁבוּעַת בִּטּוּי, שֶׁחַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנָהּ מַכּוֹת וְעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ קׇרְבָּן עוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raised an objection to Rabbi Abbahu oath I will not eat this loaf, oath I will not eat it, oath I will not eat it, and he ate it, he is liable only once. This is the oath on an utterance for which intentionally is liable lashes and unwittingly a sliding-scale offering.
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Rabbi Yirmeya to Rabbi Avahu: "A vow not to eat this loaf," "A vow not to eat it," "A vow not to eat it," and he ate it - he is only liable for one. This is the vow of false specification, for which one is liable for intentional violation with lashes, and for unintentional violation with a burnt offering and a sin offering.

hebrew_text: זוֹ הִיא – לְמַעוֹטֵי מַאי? לָאו לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ – דְּלָא לָקֵי?
human_translation: This is to exclude what? Is it not to exclude I ate, or: I did not eat, that he is not flogged?
llm_translation: This is - to exclude what? Not to exclude "I ate" and "I did not eat" - for it does not come to exclude?

hebrew_text: לָא, לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ מִקׇּרְבָּן – זוֹ הִיא דְּעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ קׇרְבָּן עוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד, אֲבָל ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ לָא. וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל הִיא, דְּאָמַר: אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא עַל הֶעָתִיד לָבֹא; אֲבָל מִילְקָא לָקֵי.
human_translation: No. to exclude I ate, or: I did not eat, from an offering. This is for which it unwittingly a sliding-scale offering. But I ate, or: I did not eat, no, And this is Rabbi Yishmael, who says: One is liable only for the future, but one is flogged
llm_translation: Not, to exclude "I ate" and "I did not eat" from the offering - this is that on her unintentional sin offering, both an elevation offering and a sin offering descend, but "I ate" and "I did not eat" do not. And Rabbi Yishmael, this is, for he said: One is liable only for what is destined to come; but not for what has already passed.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: זוֹ הִיא שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא שֶׁחַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנָהּ מַכּוֹת וְעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ פָּטוּר. זוֹ הִיא לְמַעוֹטֵי מַאי? מַאי לָאו לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ – דְּלָא לָקֵי?
human_translation: Say the latter clause This is an oath in vain, for liable lashes intentionally, and for exempt unwittingly. This is to exclude what? What, isn’t to exclude I ate, or: I did not eat, that he is not flogged?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: zo hiya shevu'at shavua shechayavin al zedonah makot ve'al shigagatah patur. Zo hiya lema'utei mai? Mai lavo lema'utei 'akhalti' ve'lo akhalti - d'lo lakei?" English translation: "The final clause: this is the oath of falsehood for which one is liable for intentional violation with lashes, but for unintentional violation one is exempt. What is the limitation? What is it not for the limitation of 'I ate' and 'I did not eat' - for it does not establish liability?"

hebrew_text: לָא; זוֹ הִיא דְּעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ פָּטוּר מִקׇּרְבָּן, אֲבָל ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ עַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ חַיָּיב קׇרְבָּן; וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הִיא, דִּמְחַיֵּיב לְשֶׁעָבַר כִּלְהַבָּא.
human_translation: No, This is for unwittingly, exempt from an offering; but I ate, or: I did not eat, is liable an offering for an unwitting And this is Rabbi Akiva, who deems liable to the past like to the future.
llm_translation: Not; this is that on her mistake exempt from offering, but "I ate" and "I did not eat" on her mistake obligated offering; and Rabbi Akiva it is, who obligates for past like future.

hebrew_text: הָא אָמְרַתְּ רֵישָׁא רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל הִיא! רֵישָׁא רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל וְסֵיפָא רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא?! כּוּלַּהּ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, וְרֵישָׁא לָאו לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ מִקׇּרְבָּן, אֶלָּא לְמַעוֹטֵי ״אוֹכַל״ וְלֹא אָכַל מִמַּלְקוֹת, אֲבָל קׇרְבָּן מִיחַיַּיב.
human_translation: But didn’t you say the first clause is Rabbi Yishmael? the first clause Rabbi Yishmael’s the latter clause Rabbi Akiva’s entire Rabbi Akiva, and the first clause not to exclude I ate, or: I did not eat, from an offering. Rather, to exclude I will eat, and did not eat, from lashes. But he is liable an offering.
llm_translation: The text: "Ha amrata reishah Rabbi Yishmael hi! Reishah Rabbi Yishmael v'seifa Rabbi Akiva?! Kulah Rabbi Akiva, v'reishah lav lema'utei 'akhalti' v'lo akhalti mikorban, ela lema'utei 'okhal' v'lo akhal mimalkot, aval korban miyachayav." Translation: "Did you say the beginning is Rabbi Yishmael? The beginning is Rabbi Yishmael and the end is Rabbi Akiva?! The entire opinion is Rabbi Akiva, and the beginning is not to exclude 'I ate' and 'I did not eat' from sacrifices, but to exclude 'eating' and not eating from fines, but regarding sacrifices, one is liable."

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא? מִסְתַּבְּרָא, קָאֵי בִּלְהַבָּא – מְמַעֵט לְהַבָּא; קָאֵי בִּלְהַבָּא – מְמַעֵט לְשֶׁעָבַר?
human_translation: And what is different It stands to reason is addressing to the future, excludes to the future, addressing to the future, excludes to the past,
llm_translation: And what is the difference? It is logical, it stands in the flame - it diminishes the flame; it stands in the flame - it diminishes the previous one.

hebrew_text: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ וְאָכַל כׇּל שֶׁהוּא, חַיָּיב כּוּ׳. אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, בְּכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ – כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ, דִּמְחַיֵּיב בְּמַשֶּׁהוּ? דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: כׇּל שֶׁהוּא לְמַכּוֹת, וְלֹא אָמְרוּ כְּזַיִת אֶלָּא לְעִנְיַן קׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: oath I will not eat, and he ate any amount, liable A dilemma was raised before Does Rabbi Akiva in the entire Torah, hold in accordance with Rabbi Shimon, who deems liable any amount As it is taught Rabbi Shimon says: any amount to lashes, and stated an olive-bulk only in the matter of an offering.
llm_translation: "An oath of not eating" and he ate anything, liable. It was asked of them: Rabbi Akiva, in the entire Torah - like Rabbi Shimon holds, that he is liable for his own? As it was taught, Rabbi Shimon says: Anything that is for lashes, and they did not say 'like an olive' except for the matter of a sacrifice.

hebrew_text: וּבְדִין הוּא דְּבָעֵי אִיפְּלוֹגֵי בְּעָלְמָא, וְהַאי דְּקָא מִיפַּלְגִי הָכָא – לְהוֹדִיעֲךָ כּוֹחָן דְּרַבָּנַן, דְּאַף עַל גַּב דְּאִיכָּא לְמֵימַר: הוֹאִיל וּמְפָרֵשׁ חַיָּיב, סְתָם נָמֵי חַיָּיב; קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּפָטְרִי.
human_translation: And by right, should have disagree in general. And that here they disagree to convey to you the far-reaching nature of the Rabbis. that even though it is to say since specifically liable, without specifying also liable, teach us that, exempt
llm_translation: It is in the law that they may argue in general, and this one who is arguing here - to inform you of the power of the Rabbis, even though there is room to say: since he explicitly stated, he is liable, even if he had stated generally, he is liable; it is implied to us that they have exempted.

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִלְמָא, בְּעָלְמָא – כְּרַבָּנַן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ; וְהָכָא הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא – הוֹאִיל וּמְפָרֵשׁ חַיָּיב, סְתָם נָמֵי חַיָּיב.
human_translation: Or perhaps, in general, holds like the Rabbis And here, this is the reason Since specifically liable, without specifying also liable.
llm_translation: Or perhaps, in general - like the Rabbis hold; and here is the reason - since when he explains he is liable, in general terms he is liable.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמְרוּ לוֹ לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: הֵיכָן מָצִינוּ בְּאוֹכֵל כָּל שֶׁהוּא חַיָּיב, שֶׁזֶּה חַיָּיב? וְאִם אִיתָא, לֵימָא לְהוּ: אֲנָא בְּכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סְבִירָא לִי!
human_translation: Come hear that said to Rabbi Akiva: Where do we find that eats any amount is liable, that this liable? If it is so let him say to them: In the entire Torah I hold in accordance with Rabbi Shimon.
llm_translation: Come and hear, for they said to Rabbi Akiva: Where do we find in one who eats anything that he is liable, that this one is liable? And if it is found, let him say to them: I hold throughout the entire Torah like Rabbi Shimon!

hebrew_text: לְדִבְרֵיהֶם דְּרַבָּנַן קָאָמַר לְהוּ: לְדִידִי, בְּכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סְבִירָא לִי. לְדִידְכוּ, אוֹדוֹ לִי מִיהָא, הוֹאִיל וּמְפָרֵשׁ חַיָּיב, סְתָם נָמֵי חַיָּיב! וַאֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ רַבָּנַן: לָא.
human_translation: is speaking to the Rabbis in accordance with their statement, As far as my opinion in the entire Torah I hold in accordance with Rabbi Shimon According to you, admit to me at least since specifically liable, without specifying also liable. And the Rabbis said to him: No,
llm_translation: Regarding their words, the sages are saying to them: According to my opinion, in the entire Torah, the view of Rabbi Shimon is plausible to me. According to your opinion, admit to me from there, since when he explains, he is liable; when he speaks in general terms, he is liable! And the sages said to him: No.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: נָזִיר שֶׁשָּׁרָה פִּתּוֹ בְּיַיִן, וְיֵשׁ בָּהּ כְּדֵי לְצָרֵף כְּזַיִת – חַיָּיב. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בְּעָלְמָא כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ, לְמָה לִי לְצָרֵף?
human_translation: Come hear Rabbi Akiva says: A nazirite who soaked his bread in wine and contain enough to combine to an olive-bulk, liable, And if it should enter your mind that he holds in accordance with Rabbi Shimon in general, why do I to combine
llm_translation: Come and hear, Rabbi Akiva says: A Nazirite who soaks his bread in wine, and it contains an olive's worth - is liable. And if according to your opinion in the world like Rabbi Shimon, he holds, why do I need to soak?

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד תְּנַן: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל נְבֵילוֹת וּטְרֵיפוֹת, שְׁקָצִים וּרְמָשִׂים – חַיָּיב. וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן פּוֹטֵר. וְהָוֵינַן בַּהּ: אַמַּאי חַיָּיב? מוּשְׁבָּע מֵהַר סִינַי הוּא! רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: בְּכוֹלֵל דְּבָרִים הַמּוּתָּרִין עִם דְּבָרִים הָאֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: And additionally, we learned oath I will not eat, and ate carcasses, or animals with a wound that will cause them to die within twelve months [ tereifot ], repugnant creatures, or creeping animals, liable; and Rabbi Shimon deems exempt. And we discussed it: Why liable He is under oath from Mount Sinai Rav and Shmuel and Rabbi Yoḥanan both, say where he incorporates permitted items, along with forbidden items.
llm_translation: We further learned: "One who takes an oath not to eat," and he ate neveilah and tereifah, detestable creatures, and creeping things - he is liable. And Rabbi Shimon exempts. And we raised a question on it: Why is he liable? He swore from Mount Sinai! Rav and Shmuel and Rabbi Yochanan, both of them said: It includes permissible matters with forbidden matters.

hebrew_text: וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אִי אַתָּה מוֹצֵא אֶלָּא אִי בִּמְפָרֵשׁ חֲצִי שִׁיעוּר – וְאַלִּיבָּא דְרַבָּנַן, אִי בִּסְתָם – וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא דְּאָמַר: אָדָם אוֹסֵר עַצְמוֹ בְּכׇל שֶׁהוּא.
human_translation: And Reish Lakish says: You find only if where specifies a half-measure, and in accordance with of the Rabbis if without specifying and in accordance with of Rabbi Akiva, who says a person renders himself prohibited from any amount
llm_translation: Reish Lakish said: If you find the prohibition only in a case where it is explicitly stated as half a measure - and according to the opinion of the Rabbis, if it is in a general statement - and according to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva who said: "A person may forbid himself in any amount."

hebrew_text: וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בְּעָלְמָא כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ, כָּל שֶׁהוּא נָמֵי מוּשְׁבָּע וְעוֹמֵד מֵהַר סִינַי הוּא! אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: בְּעָלְמָא כְּרַבָּנַן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: And if it enters your mind holds in accordance with Rabbi Shimon in general, any amount is also already under oath from Mount Sinai. Rather, not conclude from it: In general, Rabbi Akiva holds like the Rabbis, Conclude from it
llm_translation: And if your mind were to think in the world like Rabbi Shimon, he holds, anyone who is truthful and stands from Mount Sinai he is! Rather, is it not that he holds like the Rabbis in the world? Conclude from it.

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: הֵיכָן מָצִינוּ כּוּ׳. וְלָא?! וַהֲרֵי נְמָלָה! בְּרִיָּה שָׁאנֵי.
human_translation: said to Rabbi Akiva: Where do we find And not? But isn’t an ant entity is different,
llm_translation: They said to Rabbi Akiva: Where did we find this? And no?! But behold, an ant! A different creation.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי הֶקְדֵּשׁ! הָא בָּעֵינַן שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה.
human_translation: But isn’t consecrated we require worth one peruta .
llm_translation: And behold, hekdesh! The here we require equal small coin.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי מְפָרֵשׁ! מְפָרֵשׁ נָמֵי כִּבְרִיָּה דָּמֵי.
human_translation: But isn’t specifies specifies indeed comparable to entity,
llm_translation: And behold, he explains! He explains similar to the creation of the world.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי עָפָר! אֶלָּא
human_translation: But isn’t dirt? rather
llm_translation: And behold, dust! Rather

hebrew_text: תִּיפְשׁוֹט דְּבָעֵי רָבָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ וְאָכַל עָפָר, בְּכַמָּה? תִּפְשׁוֹט עַד דְּאִיכָּא כְּזַיִת! כִּי קָאָמְרִינַן – בְּמִידֵּי דְּבַר אֲכִילָה קָאָמְרִינַן.
human_translation: answer that Rava asks oath I will not eat, and ate dirt. How much in you could answer unless there is an olive-bulk When we say we say with regard to items that are edible.
llm_translation: The inquiry of Rava: "A vow of 'not eating' and he ate dust, in what quantity? Until there is the size of an olive! For we say - we speak in terms of a matter of eating."

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי קוּנָּמוֹת! קוּנָּמוֹת נָמֵי כִּמְפָרֵשׁ דָּמֵי.
human_translation: But aren’t konamot Konamot are also like specifies
llm_translation: And behold, Kunamot! Kunamot are like the explanation of Damai.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָהֶן: הֵיכָן מָצִינוּ בִּמְדַבֵּר וּמֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן, שֶׁזֶּה מְדַבֵּר וּמֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן. וְלָא?! וַהֲרֵי מְגַדֵּף! מְדַבֵּר וְאוֹסֵר קָאָמְרִינַן, וְהַאי מְדַבֵּר וְחוֹטֵא הוּא.
human_translation: said to Where do we find one who speaks and bring an offering as this speaks, and brings an offering And not? But isn’t a blasphemer We are speaking of one who speaks and generates a prohibition. And this one, is speaks and sins
llm_translation: He said to them: Where do we find in the wilderness one who brings an offering, for this one speaks and brings an offering. But is it not so?! Behold, he is a blasphemer! We say that one who speaks and prohibits, but this one speaks and sins.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי נָזִיר! מֵבִיא קׇרְבָּנוֹ עַל דִּבּוּרוֹ קָאָמְרִינַן, וְהַאי מֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן – לְאִשְׁתְּרוֹיֵי לֵיהּ חַמְרָא הוּא דְּקָא מַיְיתֵי.
human_translation: But doesn’t a nazirite We are speaking of one who brings an offering for his speaking, and this one, brings an offering in order to permit wine to himself.
llm_translation: Behold a Nazirite! When it says he brings his offering based on his statement, and this one brings an offering - it is to permit him wine that he brings it.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי הֶקְדֵּשׁ! אוֹסֵר לְעַצְמוֹ קָאָמְרִינַן, וְהַאי אוֹסֵר עַל כׇּל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ הוּא.
human_translation: But isn’t consecrated We are speaking of one who, generates a prohibition for himself, And this one, generates a prohibition for the whole world.
llm_translation: Behold the hekdesh! Prohibiting for himself is what we are saying, and this one prohibits upon the entire world entirely.

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי קוּנָּמוֹת! קָסָבַר אֵין מְעִילָה בְּקוּנָּמוֹת.
human_translation: Aren’t konamot holds there is no misuse with regard to konamot .
llm_translation: Behold, Kunamot! He holds that there is no Me'ilah in Kunamot.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מַחֲלוֹקֶת בִּסְתָם, אֲבָל בִּמְפָרֵשׁ – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל בְּכׇל שֶׁהוּא. מַאי טַעְמָא? מְפָרֵשׁ נָמֵי כִּבְרִיָּה דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Rava says: dispute where without specifying But where he specifies everyone agrees for any amount. What is the reason One who specifies like entity.
llm_translation: Rava said: A dispute in general, but in detail - the words of everyone are in everything that it is. What is the reason? Detail also resembles creation.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא: מַחְלוֹקֶת בְּ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, אֲבָל בְּ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶטְעוֹם״ – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל בְּכׇל שֶׁהוּא. פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: לִיטְעוֹם נָמֵי – כִּדְאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי; קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And Rava says: dispute where I will not eat, but where I will not taste, all agree for any amount. obvious lest you say even as people say: To taste, teaches us
llm_translation: And Rava said: The dispute is regarding "that I do not eat," but regarding "that I do not taste" - everyone agrees in every case. It is obvious! What might you have thought? To taste is similar - as people say; it is evident to us.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: מַחְלוֹקֶת בִּשְׁבוּעוֹת, אֲבָל בְּקוּנָּמוֹת – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל בְּכׇל שֶׁהוּא. מַאי טַעְמָא? קוּנָּמוֹת נָמֵי, כֵּיוָן דְּלָא קָא מַדְכַּר שְׁמָא דַּאֲכִילָה, כְּדִמְפָרֵשׁ דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Rav Pappa says: dispute with regard to oaths, but with regard to konamot , all agree any amount. What is the reason Indeed, konamot , since he did not explicitly mention eating, as if he specified
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: Dispute in weeks, but in kunamot - the words of everyone in everything that it is. What is the reason? Kunamot are also, since it does not mention the name of consumption, it is like separated blood.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: שְׁנֵי קוּנָּמוֹת מִצְטָרְפִין, שְׁתֵּי שְׁבוּעוֹת אֵין מִצְטָרְפוֹת. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: קוּנָּמוֹת כִּשְׁבוּעוֹת. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ חַיָּיב בְּכׇל שֶׁהוּא, לְמָה לִי לְצָרֵף?
human_translation: raises an objection two konamot combine two oaths do not combine. Rabbi Meir says: konamot are like oaths. And if it enters your mind liable for any amount, why do I to combine?
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: A question was raised: Two reeds combine, two weeks do not combine. Rabbi Meir says: Reeds are like weeks. And if you think that you are obligated in everything, why do I need to combine?

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר: ״אֲכִילָה מִזּוֹ עָלַי קוּנָּם״, ״אֲכִילָה מִזּוֹ עָלַי קוּנָּם״. אִי הָכִי, אַמַּאי מִצְטָרְפוֹת? סוֹף סוֹף – זִיל לְהָכָא לֵיכָּא שִׁיעוּרָא, וְזִיל לְהָכָא לֵיכָּא שִׁיעוּרָא! דְּאָמַר: ״אֲכִילָה מִשְּׁתֵּיהֶן עָלַי קוּנָּם״.
human_translation: where he said: Eating from this one is konam for me; eating from that one is konam for me. If so, why do they combine to Ultimately, go to this there is not measure, and go to that there is not measure. when he said: Eating from both of them is konam for me.
llm_translation: The text reads: "For he said: 'Eating from this one is upon me a penalty,' 'Eating from this one is upon me a penalty.' If so, why are they combined? Ultimately – go here, go there, there is a measure, and go here, go there, there is a measure! For he said: 'Eating from both of them is upon me a penalty.'"

hebrew_text: דִּכְוָותַהּ גַּבֵּי שְׁבוּעוֹת – דְּאָמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל מִשְּׁתֵּיהֶן״, אַמַּאי אֵין מִצְטָרְפִין? אָמַר רַב פִּנְחָס: שָׁאנֵי שְׁבוּעוֹת, מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁחֲלוּקוֹת לְחַטָּאוֹת, אֵין מִצְטָרְפוֹת.
human_translation: In the corresponding with regard to oaths, where he said: oath I will not eat from both of them, why do they not combine? Rav Pineḥas said: Oaths are different. Since are distinct with regard to sin-offerings, does not combine
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Dikvatah above Shvuot - de'amar: 'Shvu'ah shel lo okhal mish'tehen', ammai ein mitztarfin? Amar Rav Pinchas: sha'anei shvu'ot, mitoch she'chalukot le'chatatot, ein mitztarfot."

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: קוּנָּמוֹת כִּשְׁבוּעוֹת – בִּשְׁלָמָא שְׁבוּעוֹת, הוֹאִיל וַחֲלוּקוֹת לְחַטָּאוֹת; אֶלָּא קוּנָּמוֹת, אַמַּאי לָא? אֵיפוֹךְ – רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: שְׁבוּעוֹת כְּקוּנָּמוֹת. וְלֵית לֵיהּ לִדְרַב פִּנְחָס.
human_translation: If so, Rabbi Meir say konamot are like oaths Granted that oaths since they are distinct with regard to sin-offerings, but why do konamot not Reverse Rabbi Meir say: oaths are like konamot . and does not accept of Rav Pineḥas
llm_translation: So it is, Rabbi Meir says: "Kunamot like Shvuot - it is well according to Shvuot, since they are divided for sins; but Kunamot, why not? Turn it around - Rabbi Meir says: Shvuot like Kunamot. And it does not have it according to Rabbi Pinchas."

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אָמַר: כִּי קָאָמַר רַב פָּפָּא – לְעִנְיַן מַלְקוֹת; כִּי תַּנְיָא הָהִיא – לְעִנְיַן קׇרְבָּן, דְּבָעֵינַן שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה.
human_translation: Ravina said: When Rav Pappa says with regard to the matter of lashes. When it is taught that with regard to the matter of an offering where we require value of one peruta
llm_translation: Ravinah said: When Rav Pappa said - regarding lashes; as it was taught - regarding sacrifices, for we require similarity in a detail.

hebrew_text: לְמֵימְרָא דְּסָבְרִי רַבָּנַן יֵשׁ מְעִילָה בְּקוּנָּמוֹת?! וְהָתַנְיָא: ״כִּכָּר זוֹ הֶקְדֵּשׁ״, וַאֲכָלָהּ – בֵּין הוּא בֵּין חֲבֵירוֹ מָעַל; לְפִיכָךְ יֵשׁ לָהּ פִּדְיוֹן. ״כִּכָּר זוֹ עָלַי הֶקְדֵּשׁ״ – הֲרֵי הוּא מָעַל, חֲבֵירוֹ לֹא מָעַל; לְפִיכָךְ אֵין לָהּ פִּדְיוֹן. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: to say that the Sages hold misuse to konamot ? But isn’t it taught This loaf is consecrated, and ate it, either he or another misusing consequently, it is subject to redemption. This loaf is to me consecrated, he misusing another not misusing consequently, it is not subject to redemption. the statement of Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: In the matter where the sages hold that there is liability in cases of consecrated items?! And it was taught: "If this loaf is consecrated," and he ate it - whether he or his fellow transgressed; therefore, it requires redemption. "If this loaf is consecrated to me" - he transgressed, his fellow did not transgress; therefore, it does not require redemption. These are the words of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בֵּין הוּא וּבֵין חֲבֵירוֹ לֹא מָעַל, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין מְעִילָה בְּקוּנָּמוֹת.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: Both he and the other not misusing because there is no misuse with regard to konamot .
llm_translation: The Sages say: Between him and his fellow, he did not act treacherously, because there is no cloak in fig leaves.

hebrew_text: אֵיפוֹךְ: אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה לֹא מָעַל, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין מְעִילָה בְּקוּנָּמוֹת. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: הוּא מָעַל, וַחֲבֵירוֹ לֹא מָעַל.
human_translation: Reverse Both this one and that one not misusing because there is no misuse with regard to konamot . the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: He misuse and the other not misuse
llm_translation: Opposite: one this and one this not ascend, because there is no overlap in their measurements. The words of Rabbi Meir. And the Sages say: It ascends, and its counterpart does not ascend.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר קוּנָּמוֹת כְּשָׁבוּעוֹת – אֶלָּא קוּנָּמוֹת אִצְטְרוֹפֵי הוּא דְּלָא מִצְטָרְפִי, הָא מְעִילָה אִית בְּהוּ?! וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר: אֵין מְעִילָה בְּקוּנָּמוֹת כְּלָל!
human_translation: If so, Rabbi Meir says konamot are like oaths? konamot do not combine but misuse of consecrated property applies to them. But doesn’t Rabbi Meir say, with regard to konamot , there is no misuse at all?
llm_translation: So it is, Rabbi Meir says: "Kunamot like weeks - rather, kunamot are bundles, for they do not bundle, is there not a cloak in them?! And Rabbi Meir said: There is no cloak in kunamot at all!"

hebrew_text: לְדִבְרֵיהֶן דְּרַבָּנַן קָאָמַר לְהוּ: לְדִידִי – אֵין מְעִילָה בְּקוּנָּמוֹת כְּלָל; לְדִידְכוּ – אוֹדוֹ לִי מִיהַת דְּקוּנָּמוֹת כִּשְׁבוּעוֹת!
human_translation: he is saying to the Rabbis in accordance with their statement, According to my with regard to konamot , there is no misuse at all. According to your at least admit to me that konamot are like oaths
llm_translation: In their words, the Rabbis are saying to them: According to me - there is no cloak in the beams at all; according to you - acknowledge to me from where are the beams of the weeks!

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן – שְׁבוּעוֹת אִיכָּא דְּרַב פִּנְחָס, קוּנָּמוֹת לֵיכָּא דְּרַב פִּנְחָס.
human_translation: And the Rabbis? oaths apply of Rav Pineḥas konamot of Rav Pineḥas does not apply.
llm_translation: The sages - there are oaths of Rav Pinchas, there are reeds of Rav Pinchas.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל עָפָר – פָּטוּר. בָּעֵי רָבָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל עָפָר״, בְּכַמָּה? כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ – דַּעְתֵּיהּ אַכְּזַיִת; אוֹ דִלְמָא, כֵּיוָן דְּלָאו מִידֵּי דְּאָכְלִי אִינָשֵׁי הוּא, בְּכׇל שֶׁהוּא? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Rava says oath I will not eat, and ate dirt, exempt, Rava raises a dilemma: oath I will not eat dirt, how much in since he said: I will not eat his intention is to an olive-bulk? Or perhaps, since is not something that people eat, for any amount. shall stand
llm_translation: Rava said: "An oath of 'I will not eat,' and he ate dust - he is exempt." Rava asked: "An oath of 'I will not eat dust,' for how long?" Since he said 'I will not eat' - his intention is to be exact; or perhaps, since it is not a common thing for people to eat, for how long? This matter remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָבָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל חַרְצָן״, בְּכַמָּה? כֵּיוָן דְּמִתְאֲכִיל עַל יְדֵי תַּעֲרוֹבֶת – דַּעְתֵּיהּ אַכְּזַיִת; אוֹ דִלְמָא, כֵּיוָן דְּלָא בְּעֵינֵיהּ אָכְלִי לֵיהּ אִינָשֵׁי – דַּעְתֵּיהּ אַמַּשֶּׁהוּ? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Rava raises a dilemma: oath I will not eat a grape seed, how much in since it is eaten in a mixture, his intention is to olive-bulk Or perhaps, since people do not eat it by itself his intention is for any amount. shall stand
llm_translation: Inquiry of Rava: "An oath not to eat ḥarṣan," in how much? Once he becomes satiated through a mixture - his intent is fulfilled; or perhaps, once people do not consider it food in his eyes - his intent is nullified? This matter shall remain unresolved.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַב אָשֵׁי: נָזִיר שֶׁאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל חַרְצָן״, בְּכַמָּה? דְּכֵיוָן דִּכְזַיִת אִיסּוּרָא דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הוּא, כִּי קָא מִשְׁתְּבַע – אַהֶתֵּירָא קָא מִשְׁתְּבַע, וְדַעְתֵּיהּ אַמַּשֶּׁהוּ; אוֹ דִלְמָא, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, דַּעְתֵּיהּ אַכְּזַיִת?
human_translation: Rav Ashi raises a dilemma: a nazirite who says: oath I will not eat a grape seed, how much in that since an olive-bulk is a prohibition by Torah law, when he takes an oath he is taking the oath to that which is permitted and his intention to any amount? Or perhaps, since he said: I will not eat his intention to an olive-bulk,
llm_translation: Inquiries of Rav Ashe: A Nazirite who said, "I will take a vow not to eat cherries," for how long? Since the prohibition he is seeing is of biblical origin, when he makes a vow - he is making it conditional, and his intention is to permit it, or perhaps, since he said, "I will not eat," his intention is to prohibit it?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל נְבֵילוֹת וּטְרֵיפוֹת, שְׁקָצִים וּרְמָשִׂים – חַיָּיב. וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן פּוֹטֵר. וְהָוֵינַן בַּהּ: אַמַּאי חַיָּיב? מוּשְׁבָּע וְעוֹמֵד מֵהַר סִינַי הוּא! רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דְּאָמְרִי: בְּכוֹלֵל דְּבָרִים הַמּוּתָּרִין עִם דְּבָרִים הָאֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: Come hear oath I will not eat, and ate carcasses or tereifot , repugnant creatures or creeping animals, liable. And Rabbi Shimon deems exempt. And we discussed it: Why liable He is already under oath from Mount Sinai Rav and Shmuel and Rabbi Yoḥanan say where he incorporates permitted items, along with forbidden items.
llm_translation: Come and hear: "One who takes an oath that he will not eat," and he eats neveilah and tereifah, detestable creatures and creeping things - he is liable. And Rabbi Shimon exempts. And we were in it: Why is he liable? He swore and stood from Mount Sinai! Rav and Shmuel and Rabbi Yochanan say: Inclusive of permissible matters with forbidden matters.

hebrew_text: וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אִי אַתָּה מוֹצֵא אֶלָּא אִי בִּמְפָרֵשׁ חֲצִי שִׁיעוּר, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְרַבָּנַן; אִי בִּסְתָם, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא דְּאָמַר: אָדָם אוֹסֵר עַצְמוֹ בְּכׇל שֶׁהוּא.
human_translation: And Reish Lakish says: You find only if where specifies a half-measure and in accordance with of the Rabbis if without specifying and in accordance with of Rabbi Akiva, who says a person renders himself prohibited from any amount
llm_translation: Reish Lakish said: If you find the ruling only here, it applies only when it is explicitly stated as half a measure, and according to the view of the Rabbis. If you find it without specification, it applies according to the view of Rabbi Akiva who said: "A person restrains himself in every way."

hebrew_text: וְהָא נְבֵילָה – דְּמוּשְׁבָּע וְעוֹמֵד מֵהַר סִינַי הוּא, דְּכִי חַרְצָן לְגַבֵּי נָזִיר דָּמְיָא; וְטַעְמָא דְּפָרֵישׁ, הָא לָא פָּרֵישׁ – דַּעְתֵּיהּ אַכְּזַיִת! שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: But isn’t a carcass which one is already under oath from Mount Sinai? resembles a grape seed for a nazirite, and the reason that he specified that did not specify, his intention to an olive-bulk. Conclude from it
llm_translation: And this case of neveilah - it is like one who is sitting and standing from Mount Sinai, for the blood of a nazir is considered like that of a neveilah; and the reason for this ruling is that he separated himself from wine, but he did not separate himself - his mind is confused! Learn from this.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא תִּפְשׁוֹט דְּבָעֵי רָבָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל עָפָר״, בְּכַמָּה? תִּפְשׁוֹט דְּעַד דְּאִיכָּא כְּזַיִת – דְּהָא נְבֵילָה כְּעָפָר דָּמְיָא; וְטַעְמָא דְּפָרֵישׁ, הָא לֹא פָּרִישׁ – דַּעְתֵּיהּ אַכְּזַיִת!
human_translation: But resolve that Rava raises oath I will not eat dirt, how much in Resolve unless an olive-bulk, since a carcass resembles dirt, and the reason that he specified that did not specify, his intention is to an olive-bulk.
llm_translation: Rather, you should interpret the words of Rava: "An oath not to eat dust," how much? You should interpret that as long as there is the size of an olive - for a carcass is like dust in its blood; and the reason for separating the oath, if he did not separate - his intention is like an olive!

hebrew_text: לֹא; עָפָר – לָאו בַּר אֲכִילָה הוּא כְּלָל; נְבֵילָה – בַּת אֲכִילָה, וְאַרְיָא הוּא דִּרְבִיעַ עִילָּוַוהּ.
human_translation: No, Dirt is entirely inedible. A carcass, is edible, but a lion crouches on it,
llm_translation: Not; dust - not in food it is a general; nevelah - daughter of food, and arya is the fourth of its fat.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל וְשָׁתָה – אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״, וְאָכַל וְשָׁתָה – חַיָּיב שְׁתַּיִם. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל פַּת חִטִּין וּפַת שְׂעוֹרִין וּפַת כּוּסְּמִין – אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל פַּת חִטִּין וּפַת שְׂעוֹרִין וּפַת כּוּסְּמִין״, וְאָכַל – חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״, וְשָׁתָה מַשְׁקִין הַרְבֵּה – אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה יַיִן וְשֶׁמֶן וּדְבַשׁ״, וְשָׁתָה – חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת.
human_translation: oath I will not eat, and ate and drank, he is liable only one oath I will not eat and I will not drink, and ate and drank, liable two oath I will not eat, and ate wheat bread and barley bread and spelt bread, he is liable only one oath I will not eat wheat bread or barley bread or spelt bread, and ate liable for each and every one. oath I will not drink, and drank several liquids, he is liable only one oath I will not drink wine or oil or honey, and he drank liable for each and every one.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "An oath of 'I will not eat,' and he ate and drank - he is only liable for one. An oath of 'I will not eat and I will not drink,' and he ate and drank - he is liable for two. An oath of 'I will not eat,' and he ate bread of wheat, bread of barley, and bread of spelt - he is only liable for one. An oath of 'I will not eat bread of wheat, bread of barley, and bread of spelt,' and he ate - he is liable for each one separately. An oath of 'I will not drink,' and he drank many beverages - he is only liable for one. An oath of 'I will not drink wine, oil, and honey,' and he drank - he is liable for each one separately.

hebrew_text: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל אֳוכָלִין שֶׁאֵינָן רְאוּיִן לַאֲכִילָה, וְשָׁתָה מַשְׁקִין שֶׁאֵינָן רְאוּיִן לִשְׁתִיָּה – פָּטוּר. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל נְבֵילוֹת וּטְרֵיפוֹת, שְׁקָצִים וּרְמָשִׂים – חַיָּיב. וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן פּוֹטֵר. אָמַר: ״קוּנָּם אִשְׁתִּי נֶהֱנֵית לִי אִם אָכַלְתִּי הַיּוֹם״, וְהוּא אָכַל נְבֵילוֹת וּטְרֵיפוֹת, שְׁקָצִים וּרְמָשִׂים – הֲרֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ אֲסוּרָה.
human_translation: oath I will not eat, and he ate foods that are inedible or drank liquids that are not potable, exempt. oath I will not eat, and ate carcasses or tereifot , repugnant creatures or creeping animals, liable. And Rabbi Shimon deems exempt, said: konam my wife to derive benefit from me if I ate today, and he had eaten carcasses or tereifot , repugnant creatures or creeping animals, his wife is prohibited
llm_translation: "An oath not to eat," and he ate non-kosher foods, and drank beverages not fit for drinking - he is exempt. "An oath not to eat," and he ate carrion and torn animals, detestable creatures and vermin - he is liable. But Rabbi Shimon exempts. He said: "If I benefit from my wife if I eat today," and he ate carrion and torn animals, detestable creatures and vermin - behold, his wife is forbidden.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אָבִין אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְשָׁתָה – חַיָּיב. אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא סְבָרָא, וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא קְרָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin says Shmuel says: oath I will not eat, and he drank, liable. If you wish, propose a logical argument and if you wish, cite a verse
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said Rabbi Chiya bar Avin said Shmuel: "An oath of not eating," and he drank - liable. If you wish, say logic, and if you wish, say scripture.

hebrew_text: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא סְבָרָא – דַּאֲמַר לֵיהּ אִינָשׁ לְחַבְרֵיהּ: ״נִטְעוֹם מִידֵּי״, וְעָיְילִי וְאָכְלִי וְשָׁתוּ. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא קְרָא – שְׁתִיָּה בִּכְלַל אֲכִילָה; דְּאָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: מִנַּיִן לִשְׁתִיָּה שֶׁהִיא בִּכְלַל אֲכִילָה? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאָכַלְתָּ לִפְנֵי ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ בַּמָּקוֹם אֲשֶׁר יִבְחַר לְשַׁכֵּן שְׁמוֹ שָׁם מַעְשַׂר דְּגָנְךָ וְתִירֹשְׁךָ״;
human_translation: If you wish, propose a logical argument that a person will say to another: Let’s a taste something, and they go in and eat and drink. And if you wish, cite a verse as Reish Lakish says: From where that drinking is included in eating? It is from that is stated: “And you shall eat before the Lord your God, in the place that He shall choose to cause His name to dwell there, the tithe of your grain, of your tirosh ,
llm_translation: If you will say reasoning - that a person said to his friend: "Plant it and they will come, and they will go and eat and drink." And if you will say scripture - drinking is included in eating; as Reish Lakish said: From where do we derive that drinking is included in eating? As it is stated: "And you shall eat before the Lord your God, in the place that He will choose to establish His name there, the tithe of your grain, your wine."

hebrew_text: וְתִירוֹשׁ חַמְרָא הוּא, וּכְתִיב: ״וְאָכַלְתָּ״.
human_translation: And tirosh is wine, and it is written “And you shall eat,”
llm_translation: And wine is vinegar, and it is written: "And you shall eat."

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא עַל יְדֵי אֲנִיגְרוֹן? דְּאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל: אֲנִיגְרוֹן – מַיָּא דְּסִילְקֵי, אַכְּסִיגְרוֹן – מַיָּא דְּכוּלְּהוּ סִילְקִי.
human_translation: But perhaps by means of an anigeron , as Rabba bar Shmuel says: Anigeron a stew of beet greens aksigeron stew of all types of cooked
llm_translation: Perhaps through Anigron? For Rabba bar Shmuel said: Anigron - water of the rivers, Aksigron - water of all the rivers.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב, מֵהָכָא: ״וְנָתַתָּה הַכֶּסֶף בְּכֹל אֲשֶׁר תְּאַוֶּה נַפְשְׁךָ, בַּבָּקָר וּבַצֹּאן וּבַיַּיִן וּבַשֵּׁכָר״; יַיִן חַמְרָא הוּא, וּכְתִיב: ״וְאָכַלְתָּ״.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: from here, “And you shall bestow the money for whatsoever your soul desires, for oxen, or for sheep, or for wine [ uvayyayin ], or for strong drink, yayin is wine, and it is written: “And you shall eat.”
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Acha bar Yaakov said from here: "And you shall spend the money for whatever your soul desires, for oxen or for sheep or for wine or for strong drink." Wine is synonymous with vinegar, as it is written: "And you shall eat."

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא הָכָא נָמֵי עַל יְדֵי אֲנִיגְרוֹן?
human_translation: But perhaps here also by means of an anigeron .
llm_translation: And perhaps here it is stated by means of Anigron?

hebrew_text: ״שֵׁכָר״ כְּתִיב, מִידֵּי דִּמְשַׁכַּר.
human_translation: “Strong drink” is written something intoxicating,
llm_translation: "Shēkhār" is written, from the hand of "dīmshakkar."

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא דְּבֵילָה קְעִילִית? דְּתַנְיָא: אָכַל דְּבֵילָה קְעִילִית וְשָׁתָה דְּבַשׁ וְחָלָב, וְנִכְנַס לַמִּקְדָּשׁ וְעָבַד – חַיָּיב.
human_translation: But perhaps figs from Ke’ila, as it is taught ate figs from Ke’ila or drank honey or milk and entered the Temple and performed liable
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And perhaps it is considered a mixture of forbidden fats? For it was taught: One who ate a mixture of forbidden fats and drank honey and milk, and then entered the Temple and performed the service - is liable.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא גָּמַר ״שֵׁכָר״–״שֵׁכָר״ מִנָּזִיר; מָה לְהַלָּן יַיִן, אַף כָּאן יַיִן.
human_translation: Rather, derives “strong drink” from a nazirite: strong drink: Just as there, wine, so too here, wine.
llm_translation: Rather, he concluded "wine" - "wine" from Nazir; just as there it refers to wine, so too here it refers to wine.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא, אַף אֲנַן נָמֵי תְּנֵינָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל וְשָׁתָה – אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא שְׁתִיָּה בִּכְלַל אֲכִילָה, אִיצְטְרִיךְ לֵיהּ לְתַנָּא לְאַשְׁמוֹעִינַן דְּאֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ שְׁתִיָּה לָאו בִּכְלַל אֲכִילָה, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל וְעָשָׂה מְלָאכָה – מִי אִיצְטְרִיךְ לְאַשְׁמוֹעִינַן דְּאֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת?!
human_translation: Rava said: We learn as well oath I will not eat, and ate and drank, he is liable only one Granted, if you say drinking is included in eating, it was necessary for the tanna to teach us that he is liable only one But if you say drinking is not included in eating, oath I will not eat, and he ate and performed labor, would it be necessary to teach us that liable only one
llm_translation: Rava said, "We also learned: 'An oath not to eat,' and he ate and drank - he is only liable for one. If you say that drinking is included in eating, the Mishnah needed to teach us that he is only liable for one. But if you say that drinking is not included in eating, 'an oath not to eat,' and he ate and performed labor - who needed to teach us that he is only liable for one?!"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: אֶלָּא מַאי, שְׁתִיָּה בִּכְלַל אֲכִילָה?! אֵימָא סֵיפָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״, וְאָכַל וְשָׁתָה – חַיָּיב שְׁתַּיִם. כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ – אִיתְּסַר לֵיהּ בִּשְׁתִיָּה; כִּי אָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״ – אַמַּאי חַיָּיב? אִילּוּ אָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״ תְּרֵי זִימְנֵי, מִי מִיחַיַּיב תַּרְתֵּי?!
human_translation: Abaye said to him: What, rather, drinking is included in eating? Say the latter clause oath I will not eat and I will not drink, and ate and drank, liable two once he said: I will not eat, drinking became forbidden to him, when he said: I will not drink, why liable If he had said: I will not drink, two times, would he be liable two
llm_translation: He said to him, Abaye: Rather, what, drinking included in eating?! Say the latter part: "A vow not to eat and not to drink," and he ate and drank - he is liable for two. Since he said "not to eat" - he is prohibited from drinking; when he said "not to drink" - why is he liable? If he said "not to drink" two times, who would make him liable for two?!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָתָם דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״, וַהֲדַר אָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״; דִּשְׁתִיָּה בִּכְלַל אֲכִילָה אִיתַהּ, אֲכִילָה בִּכְלָל שְׁתִיָּה לֵיתַהּ.
human_translation: said to him: There, where he said: I will not drink, and then said: I will not eat. it is that drinking is included in eating, it is not eating is included in drinking,
llm_translation: He said to him: There, where he said "I will not drink," and then he said "I will not eat"; drinking includes eating, but eating does not include drinking.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל אָמַר שְׁבוּעָה ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״, וְאָכַל וְשָׁתָה, מַאי – אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת? אִי הָכִי, אַדְּתָנֵי רֵישָׁא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ וְאָכַל וְשָׁתָה אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת; לִיתְנֵי: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״ אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת – וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ לְחוֹדֵיהּ!
human_translation: But he said: oath I will not eat and I will not drink, and he ate and drank, what he is liable only one If that is so, rather than teaching the first clause oath I will not eat, and ate and drank, is liable only one let teach oath I will not eat and I will not drink, he is liable only one I will not eat, alone, all the more so
llm_translation: Talmudic text: But if one takes an oath saying, "I will not eat and I will not drink," and then eats and drinks, what is the ruling? Is he liable for only one offense? If so, let the first clause be taught: "An oath not to eat," and he eats and drinks, he is liable for only one offense; let it be taught: "An oath not to eat and not to drink," he is liable for only one offense - all the more so for "an oath not to eat" by itself!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְעוֹלָם כִּדְקָתָנֵי; וְשָׁאנֵי הָכָא, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ וַהֲדַר אָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״ – גַּלִּי אַדַּעְתֵּיהּ דְּהָךְ אֲכִילָה דְּאָמַר, אֲכִילָה גְּרֵידְתָּא הִיא.
human_translation: Rather, actually as it is taught, And here is different. Since he said: I will not eat, and then said: I will not drink, he revealed his intention that the eating that he stated is eating alone
llm_translation: Rather, forever as it is taught; and here is different, since he said "I will not eat" and then he said "I will not drink" - reveal his intention that the eating he mentioned is a mere formality.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי, מַתְנִיתִין נָמֵי דַּיְקָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל אֳוכָלִין שֶׁאֵין רְאוּיִן לַאֲכִילָה, וְשָׁתָה מַשְׁקִין שֶׁאֵין רְאוּיִן לִשְׁתִיָּה – פָּטוּר. הָא רְאוּיִן – חַיָּיב; וְאַמַּאי? הָא ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ קָאָמַר!
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: The mishna is also precisely oath I will not eat, and he ate foods that are inedible or drank liquids that are not potable, exempt. But fit liable. And why? saying: oath I will not eat,
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said, the Mishnah also states precisely: "An oath not to eat," and he ate unfit foods for consumption, and drank beverages not fit for drinking - he is exempt. If they are fit - he is liable; and why? Because he took an oath not to eat!

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא דְּאָמַר תַּרְתֵּי: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״.
human_translation: Perhaps where he said both: oath I will not eat oath I will not drink.
llm_translation: Perhaps one says two: "a week that I will not eat," "a week that I will not drink."

hebrew_text: שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל, וְאָכַל פַּת חִטִּין כּוּ׳. וְדִלְמָא לְמִיפְטַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ מֵאַחְרָנְיָיתָא קָאָתֵי?
human_translation: oath I will not eat, and ate wheat bread But perhaps comes to exempts himself from other
llm_translation: Oath of not eating, and he ate a piece of wheat bread. And perhaps he is coming to exempt himself from the final liability?

hebrew_text: הֲוָה לֵיהּ לְמֵימַר ״חִטִּין וּשְׂעוֹרִין וְכוּסְּמִין״. וְדִלְמָא לָכוֹס?
human_translation: he could have said: Wheat, barley, and spelt, But perhaps to chewing [ lakhos ]
llm_translation: He had to say "wheat, barley, and sesame." But perhaps it should be "flax"?

hebrew_text: דַּהֲוָה לֵיהּ לְמֵימַר ״פַּת חִטִּין וּשְׂעוֹרִין וְכוּסְּמִין״. וְדִלְמָא ״פַּת חִטִּין״ – לֶאֱכוֹל, ״שְׂעוֹרִין וְכוּסְּמִין״ – לָכוֹס?
human_translation: he could have said: Bread wheat, or barley, or spelt, perhaps eating wheat bread chewing barley or spelt.
llm_translation: It was to him to say, "bread of wheat and barley and spelt." And perhaps "bread of wheat" - to eat, "barley and spelt" - to drink?

hebrew_text: דַּהֲוָה לֵיהּ לְמֵימַר ״פַּת חִטִּין וְשֶׁל שְׂעוֹרִין וְשֶׁל כּוּסְּמִין״.
human_translation: he could have said: Bread wheat, and from barley, and from spelt,
llm_translation: It was said to him to say, "bread of wheat and of barley and of spelt."

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא עַל יְדֵי תַּעֲרוֹבֶת?
human_translation: But perhaps from a mixture
llm_translation: And perhaps by means of a mixture?

hebrew_text: אֵימָא ״וְכֵן שֶׁל שְׂעוֹרִים וְכֵן שֶׁל כּוּסְּמִין״; ״פַּת״ ״פַּת״ לְמָה לִי? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ לְחַלֵּק.
human_translation: say: and so from barley and so from spelt. Why do I Bread, bread, Conclude from it to individuate
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima 've'chen shel se'orim ve'chen shel kusmin'; 'pat' 'pat' l'mah li? Shema minah l'chalek." English translation: "Say, 'And similarly with barley and similarly with spelt'; 'bread' 'bread' why do I need it? Learn from it to divide."

hebrew_text: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה״ וְשָׁתָה מַשְׁקִין הַרְבֵּה, אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת כּוּ׳. בִּשְׁלָמָא הָתָם, דְּאָמְרַתְּ מְיַיתְּרָא לֵיהּ ״פַּת״ ״פַּת״ לְחִיּוּבָא; אֶלָּא הָכָא, מַאי הֲוָה לְמֵימַר? דִּלְמָא לְמִיפְטַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ מִמַּשְׁקִין אַחֲרִינֵי קָאָתֵי!
human_translation: oath I will not drink, and he drank several liquids, he is liable only one Granted, there, as you said bread bread are superfluous to liability But here, what was there to say? Perhaps comes to exempts himself to other liquids.
llm_translation: "An oath not to drink" and he drank many beverages, he is liable only once. It is understandable there, as you say, "bread" "bread" for obligation; but here, what could one say? Perhaps he intended to save himself from other drinks!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הָכָא בְּמוּנָּחִין לְפָנָיו עָסְקִינַן, שֶׁהָיָה לוֹ לוֹמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה אֵלּוּ״. וְדִלְמָא אֵלּוּ הוּא דְּלָא שָׁתֵינָא, אַחֲרִינֵי שָׁתֵינָא?
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: We are dealing here with placed before him. he could have said: oath I will not drink these. But perhaps It is these that I will not drink, I will drink other
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: Here we are dealing with a case of "munachin" before him, for he should have said, "I swear that I will not drink these." But perhaps these are not the ones that he did not drink; are they others that he did drink?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא דְּאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה דְּלָא שָׁתֵינָא כְּגוֹן אֵלּוּ״. דִּלְמָא כְּגוֹן אֵלּוּ דְּלָא שָׁתֵינָא; בְּצִיר מֵהָכִי וּטְפֵי מֵהָכִי שָׁתֵינָא?
human_translation: Rather, where he said: oath I will not drink such as these. perhaps I will not drink such as these, I will drink less than this or more than this.
llm_translation: Rather, he said, "An oath that I did not drink, such as these." Perhaps "such as these" that I did not drink; in the case of this amount and that amount did he drink?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה מִמִּין אֵלּוּ״. וְדִלְמָא מִין אֵלּוּ הוּא דְּלָא שָׁתֵינָא, הָא אִינְהוּ גּוּפַיְיהוּ שָׁתֵינָא?
human_translation: Rather, where he said: oath I will not drink from these types But perhaps I will not drink these types but I will drink these particular
llm_translation: Rather, for example, as he said: "An oath not to drink from these kinds." And perhaps these are not the kinds that we are not drinking, but they themselves are drinking?

hebrew_text: אֵימָא ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה אֵלּוּ וּמִינַּיְיהוּ״.
human_translation: say: I will not drink these and their types.
llm_translation: "Why should I not drink these and their types?"

hebrew_text: רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִיקָא אָמַר: בִּמְסַרְהֵב בּוֹ חֲבֵירוֹ עָסְקִינַן, דְּאָמַר לוֹ: ״בּוֹא וּשְׁתֵה עִמִּי יַיִן וְשֶׁמֶן וּדְבַשׁ״. דְּהָיָה לוֹ לוֹמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה עִמְּךָ״, ״יַיִן וְשֶׁמֶן וּדְבַשׁ״ לְמָה לִי? לְחַיֵּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: We are dealing with which another is importuning him as said to him: Come, drink wine, and oil, and honey with me; he should have said: oath I will not drink with you. why do I Wine, and oil, and honey? to render liable for each and every one.
llm_translation: Rav Acha, son of Rav Ika, said: We are dealing with a case where his friend invited him to partake with him, for he said to him, "Come and drink wine, oil, and honey with me." He should have said to him, "I swear that I will not drink with you." Why do I need wine, oil, and honey? To obligate him for each and every one.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן הָתָם: ״תֵּן לִי חִטִּין וּשְׂעוֹרִין וְכוּסְּמִין שֶׁיֵּשׁ לִי בְּיָדְךָ״, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֵין לְךָ בְּיָדִי כְּלוּם״ – אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֵין לְךָ בְּיָדִי חִטִּין וּשְׂעוֹרִין וְכוּסְּמִין״ – חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת.
human_translation: We learned elsewhere Give me my wheat, barley, and spelt in your possession, oath nothing of yours is in my possession, he is liable only one oath I do not have in my possession wheat, barley, or spelt that belong to you, liable for each and every one.
llm_translation: We learned there: "Give me wheat, barley, and spelt that I have in your possession," "An oath that you have nothing in my possession" - he is only liable once. "An oath that you have nothing in my possession of wheat, barley, and spelt" - he is liable for each and every one.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אֲפִילּוּ פְּרוּטָה מִכּוּלָּם מִצְטָרֶפֶת.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan says even of all combines peruta .
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yochanan said: Even a small coin among all of them combines.

hebrew_text: פְּלִיגִי בַּהּ רַב אַחָא וְרָבִינָא; חַד אָמַר: אַפְּרָטֵי מִיחַיַּיב, אַכְּלָלֵי לָא מִיחַיַּיב; וְחַד אָמַר: אַכְּלָלֵי נָמֵי מִיחַיַּיב.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree with regard to this. One said: he is liable for specific he is not liable for And one said: He is also liable for
llm_translation: They disputed it, Rav Acha and Ravina; one said: Specifics are liable, but generalities are not liable; and one said: Generalities are also liable.

hebrew_text: הָכָא מַאי?
human_translation: Here, what
llm_translation: Here, what is the matter?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! הָתָם מִיחַיַּיב אַכְּלָלָא וּמִיחַיַּיב אַפְּרָטָא, דְּהָא אִי מִשְׁתְּבַע וַהֲדַר מִשְׁתְּבַע – מִיחַיַּיב תַּרְתֵּי. הָכָא, אִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ אִיתָא בִּכְלָלָא, אַפְּרָטֵי אַמַּאי מִיחַיַּיב? מוּשְׁבָּע וְעוֹמֵד הוּא!
human_translation: Rava said: How can be compared? There, liable for general and for specific since if takes an oath and then takes another oath liable two Here, if it enters your mind he is bound by a general why would he be liable for the specific He is already under an oath
llm_translation: Rava said: Is it so now?! There, he is liable for the general principle and liable for the specific detail, for if he retracts and then retracts again - he is liable twice. Here, if it occurs to you in the general principle, why is he liable for the specific detail? He is sitting and standing!

hebrew_text: שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל וְכוּ׳. הָא גוּפַאּ קַשְׁיָא – אָמְרַתְּ: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל אֳוכָלִין שֶׁאֵין רְאוּיִן לַאֲכִילָה וְשָׁתָה מַשְׁקִין שֶׁאֵין רְאוּיִן לִשְׁתִיָּה – פָּטוּר; וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל נְבֵילוֹת וּטְרֵיפוֹת, שְׁקָצִים וּרְמָשִׂים – חַיָּיב; מַאי שְׁנָא רֵישָׁא דְּפָטוּר, וּמַאי שְׁנָא סֵיפָא דְּחַיָּיב?
human_translation: oath I will not eat, This itself difficult. You said oath I will not eat, and he ate foods that are inedible, or drank liquids that are not potable, exempt. And then teaches oath I will not eat, and ate unslaughtered carcasses or tereifot , repugnant creatures or creeping animals, liable. What is different the first clause that exempt and what is different the latter clause that liable?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: A week that one does not eat, etc. This itself is difficult - you said, "A week that one does not eat," and he ate unfit foods for eating and drank unfit drinks for drinking - he is exempt; and then it teaches: "A week that one does not eat," and he ate neveilahs and tereifahs, abominations, and creeping things - he is liable; what is different about the first case that he is exempt, and what is different about the latter case that he is liable?

hebrew_text: הָא לָא קַשְׁיָא; רֵישָׁא בִּסְתָם, וְסֵיפָא בִּמְפָרֵשׁ.
human_translation: This not difficult. The first clause where without specifying And the latter clause where he specifies
llm_translation: Here is the English word-for-word translation of the Talmudic text: Talmudic text: This is not difficult; the beginning in a general statement, and the end in a detailed explanation.

hebrew_text: מְפָרֵשׁ נָמֵי גּוּפֵיהּ תִּיקְשֵׁי – אַמַּאי מוּשְׁבָּע מֵהַר סִינַי הוּא?
human_translation: You may also raise a difficulty specifies Why? He is under oath from Mount Sinai,
llm_translation: Explains Naḥum his body, it is difficult - why is it sworn from Mount Sinai?

hebrew_text: רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דְּאָמְרִי: בְּכוֹלֵל דְּבָרִים הַמּוּתָּרִין עִם דְּבָרִים הָאֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: Rav and Shmuel and Rabbi Yoḥanan say where he incorporates permitted items, along with forbidden items.
llm_translation: Rav and Shmuel and Rabbi Yochanan said: In the general category of permissible matters with forbidden matters.

hebrew_text: וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אִי אַתָּה מוֹצֵא אֶלָּא אִי בִּמְפָרֵשׁ חֲצִי שִׁיעוּר – וְאַלִּיבָּא דְרַבָּנַן; אִי בִּסְתָם – אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, דְּאָמַר: אָדָם אוֹסֵר עַצְמוֹ בְּכׇל שֶׁהוּא.
human_translation: And Reish Lakish says: You find only if where specifies a half-measure, and in accordance with of the Rabbis if without specifying in accordance with of Rabbi Akiva, who says a person renders himself prohibited from any amount
