llm_translation: Reish Lakish said: If you find the ruling only in a case where it is explicitly stated as half the measure - then we follow the view of the Rabbis; if it is found in a general statement - then we follow the view of Rabbi Akiva, who said: "A person restrains himself in every way."

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לָא אָמַר כְּרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ – דְּמוֹקֵים לָהּ לְמַתְנִיתִין כְּדִבְרֵי הַכֹּל; אֶלָּא רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, מַאי טַעְמָא לָא אָמַר כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן?
human_translation: Granted, Rabbi Yoḥanan did not say like Reish Lakish, as he interprets the mishna in accordance with the opinion of everyone; but what is the reason that Reish Lakish does not say like Rabbi Yoḥanan?
llm_translation: In truth, Rabbi Yochanan did not say like Reish Lakish - they establish it according to the Mishnah like the words of everyone; rather Reish Lakish, what is the reason he did not say like Rabbi Yochanan?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְךָ: כִּי אָמְרִינַן אִיסּוּר כּוֹלֵל –
human_translation: say to you: When we say inclusive prohibition,
llm_translation: He said to you: for we say, "issur kollel" -

hebrew_text: בְּאִיסּוּר הַבָּא מֵאֵלָיו; בְּאִיסּוּר הַבָּא עַל יְדֵי עַצְמוֹ לָא אָמְרִינַן.
human_translation: with regard to a prohibition that occurs on its own, with regard to a prohibition that occurs by himself, we do not say
llm_translation: In a prohibition that comes from itself; in a prohibition that comes by itself we do not say.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, מִשּׁוּם הָכִי קָא פָטַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן; דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: כׇּל שֶׁהוּא לְמַכּוֹת, וְלֹא אָמְרוּ כְּזַיִת אֶלָּא לְקׇרְבָּן. אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן דְּפָטַר?
human_translation: Granted, according to Reish Lakish, due to this Rabbi Shimon deems exempt as it is taught Rabbi Shimon says: Any amount to lashes, and stated an olive-bulk only to an offering. But according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, what is the reason that Rabbi Shimon deems one exempt
llm_translation: Talmudic text: In truth, according to Reish Lakish, because of this Rabbi Shimon exempted; as it was taught, Rabbi Shimon says: Anyone who is liable for lashes, and they did not say "like an olive" but rather "for a sacrifice." But according to Rabbi Yochanan, what is the reason that Rabbi Shimon exempted?

hebrew_text: מִידֵּי הוּא טַעְמָא – אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם אִיסּוּר כּוֹלֵל; רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן לְטַעְמֵיהּ דְּלֵית לֵיהּ אִיסּוּר כּוֹלֵל. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: הָאוֹכֵל נְבֵילָה בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים – פָּטוּר.
human_translation: Isn’t the reason only that a more inclusive prohibition? Rabbi Shimon to his reasoning that he does not hold inclusive prohibition that which is taught Rabbi Shimon says: One who eats non-kosher meat on Yom Kippur exempt
llm_translation: From him is the reason - rather because of a general prohibition; Rabbi Shimon according to his reasoning that there is no general prohibition. As it was taught, Rabbi Shimon says: One who eats neveilah on Yom Kippur - is exempt.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ בְּלָאו וָהֵן; אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, בִּשְׁלָמָא לָאו – מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ, אֶלָּא הֵן – הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ?
human_translation: Granted, according to Reish Lakish, you find where negative or positive. But according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, granted, you can find a negative But how can you find a positive
llm_translation: In peace to Reish Lakish, she finds it with a negative and they; but to Rabbi Yochanan, in peace it is not - she finds it, but they - how does she find it?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא כִּדְרָבָא, דְּאָמַר רָבָא: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל עָפָר – פָּטוּר.
human_translation: Rather, in accordance with that which Rava as Rava says oath I will not eat, and ate dirt, is exempt,
llm_translation: Rather like Rava, for Rava said: "An oath not to eat," and he ate dust - he is exempt.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב מָרִי, אַף אֲנַן נָמֵי תְּנֵינָא: ״קוּנָּם אִשְׁתִּי נֶהֱנֵית לִי אִם אָכַלְתִּי הַיּוֹם״, וְאָכַל נְבֵילוֹת וּטְרֵיפוֹת, שְׁקָצִים וּרְמָשִׂים – הֲרֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ אֲסוּרָה לוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Mari said: We learn as well konam my wife to derive benefit from me if I ate today, and he had eaten carcasses or tereifot , repugnant creatures or creeping animals, his wife is prohibited him.
llm_translation: Rav Mari said, "We also learned: 'If my wife is pleasing to me if I eat today,' and he ate neveilah and terefah, abominations and creeping things - his wife is forbidden to him."

hebrew_text: הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! הָתָם, כֵּיוָן דְּמֵעִיקָּרָא (אכל) [אַכְלֵיהּ] וַהֲדַר אִשְׁתְּבַע (ליה) [עֲלֵיהּ],
human_translation: How can be compared? There, since he initially ate and then took an oath
llm_translation: So, is it really so?! There, since he initially ate it and then became satisfied with it,

hebrew_text: (חשובי) [אַחְשׁוֹבֵי]; אֶלָּא הָכָא מִי אַחְשְׁבֵיהּ?!
human_translation: he granted significance to But here, did he give significance to it?
llm_translation: (חשובי) Achshovei; rather here, who is Achshveih?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּמַאן דְּאִית לֵיהּ אִיסּוּר כּוֹלֵל?
human_translation: Rava says: What is the reasoning of the one who holds inclusive prohibition
llm_translation: Rava said: What is the reason that one who has a prohibition against him includes everything?

hebrew_text: מִידֵּי דְּהָוֵה אַאִיסּוּר מוֹסִיף.
human_translation: It is just as it is of an expanded prohibition,
llm_translation: From the time that the prohibition was added.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּפָטַר, דְּלֵית לֵיהּ? כִּי אָמַר אִיסּוּר מוֹסִיף – בַּחֲדָא חֲתִיכָה, בִּשְׁתֵּי חֲתִיכוֹת לָא אָמְרִינַן.
human_translation: And the one who exempts as he does not hold When he says an expanded prohibition with regard to a single piece, With regard to two pieces, we do not say
llm_translation: And who exempts, that he does not have? For he said, a prohibition adds - in one piece, in two pieces we do not say.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא: לְמַאן דְּאִית לֵיהּ אִיסּוּר כּוֹלֵל, אָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים״, וְחָזַר וְאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים וַעֲנָבִים״ – מִיגּוֹ דְּחָיְילָא שְׁבוּעָה אַעֲנָבִים, חָיְילָא נָמֵי אַתְּאֵנִים.
human_translation: And Rava says: According to the one who holds inclusive prohibition says: oath I will not eat figs, and then says: oath I will not eat figs and grapes, since takes effect with regard to the grapes, it also takes effect with regard to the figs,
llm_translation: And Rava said: For one who has a general prohibition, he said, "A vow not to eat figs," and then he repeated and said, "A vow not to eat figs and grapes" - from the fact that he included grapes in the vow, it is evident that figs are also included.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא!
human_translation: obvious?
llm_translation: The Talmudic text "פְּשִׁיטָא!" can be translated into English as "It is obvious!"

hebrew_text: מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: אִיסּוּר הַבָּא מֵאֵלָיו אָמְרִינַן, אִיסּוּר הַבָּא מֵעַצְמוֹ לָא אָמְרִינַן; קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Lest you say we say a prohibition that occurs on its own, a prohibition that occurs by himself we do not say teaches us
llm_translation: What is the reasoning? We say that a prohibition that comes from itself, we do not say it is permitted, a prohibition that comes from elsewhere, we say it is permitted; this is implied to us.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רָבָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבָּה: יֵשׁ אוֹכֵל אֲכִילָה אַחַת, וְחַיָּיב עָלֶיהָ אַרְבַּע חַטָּאוֹת וְאָשָׁם אֶחָד; וְאֵלּוּ הֵן: טָמֵא שֶׁאָכַל חֵלֶב, וְהוּא נוֹתָר, מִן הַמּוּקְדָּשִׁין, בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים.
human_translation: Rava, son of Rabba, raises an objection It is perform one eating for which liable four sin-offerings and one guilt-offering. And these are A ritually impure who ate fat that is the leftover from the sacrificial on Yom Kippur.
llm_translation: Rava son of Rabba raised an objection: Is there one who eats one portion, and is liable for it four sin-offerings and one guilt-offering; and these are they: one who is impure who ate fat, and he remained, from the holy things, on the Day of Atonement.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: אַף אִם הָיְתָה שַׁבָּת וְהוֹצִיאוֹ – חַיָּיב. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: אֵינוֹ מִן הַשֵּׁם.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir says: Also, if it was Shabbat and he transferred liable said to him: This is not of the type,
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir says: Even if it was Shabbat and he carried it out - he is liable. They said to him: It is not from the name.

hebrew_text: וְאִם אִיתָא, מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ חָמֵשׁ – כְּגוֹן שֶׁאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּמָרִים וְחֵלֶב״, מִיגּוֹ דְּחָיְילָא שְׁבוּעָה אַתְּמָרִים, חָיְילָא נָמֵי אַחֵלֶב!
human_translation: And if it is so you find five such as where says oath I will not eat dates and fat. Since takes effect with regard to the dates, it also takes effect with regard to the fat.
llm_translation: If it is found, she finds for herself five - for example, that he said, "An oath that I will not eat dates and fat," from the fact that he annulled the oath regarding dates, he must also annul it regarding fat!

hebrew_text: כִּי קָתָנֵי, אִיסּוּר הַבָּא מֵאֵלָיו; אִיסּוּר הַבָּא מֵעַצְמוֹ לָא קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: When teaches prohibitions that occur on their own he does not teach prohibitions that occur by himself.
llm_translation: When it is taught, a prohibition that comes from itself; a prohibition that comes from another is not taught.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי הֶקְדֵּשׁ!
human_translation: But doesn’t consecrated
llm_translation: And behold, hekdesh!

hebrew_text: בִּבְכוֹר, דִּקְדוּשָּׁתוֹ מֵרֶחֶם.
human_translation: a first-born whose sanctity is from the womb,
llm_translation: In the firstborn, his sanctity is from the womb.

hebrew_text: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: כִּי קָתָנֵי, מִידֵּי דְּלֵית לֵיהּ שְׁאֵלָה; שְׁבוּעָה דְּאִית לֵיהּ שְׁאֵלָה לָא קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: If you wish, say when teaches matters to which a request do not apply. An oath, to which a request applies, is not taught.
llm_translation: If you ask, say: When it is taught, from the hands of one who does not have a question; an oath that has a question is not taught.

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי הֶקְדֵּשׁ!
human_translation: Doesn’t consecrated
llm_translation: Behold, hekdesh!

hebrew_text: הָא אוֹקְמִינַן בִּבְכוֹר.
human_translation: Didn’t we establish a firstborn
llm_translation: We establish with a bechor.

hebrew_text: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: כִּי קָתָנֵי, קׇרְבָּן קָבוּעַ; קׇרְבָּן עוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד לָא קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: If you wish, say when he teaches a fixed offering. a sliding-scale offering, does not teach
llm_translation: If you wish, say: When it is taught, a fixed offering; an olah offering that ascends and descends is not taught.

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי טָמֵא שֶׁאָכַל אֶת הַקֹּדֶשׁ – דְּקׇרְבָּן עוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד הוּא!
human_translation: Doesn’t an impure who ate consecrated which is a sliding-scale offering?
llm_translation: Behold, impure who ate the holy - like burnt offering and descending he is!

hebrew_text: בְּנָשִׂיא, וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הִיא דְּאָמַר: נָשִׂיא מֵבִיא שָׂעִיר.
human_translation: to a king and is Rabbi Eliezer, who says: king brings goat
llm_translation: In the prince, and Rabbi Eliezer is the one who said: "A prince brings a he-goat."

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: כִּי קָתָנֵי, מִידֵּי דְּבָעֵי שִׁיעוּר; שְׁבוּעָה דְּחָיְילָא אַפָּחוֹת מִכְּשִׁיעוּר, לָא קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said When teaches matters that apply measure an oath, which applies to less than measure, is not taught
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: When it is taught, it is from the hands of those who require measurement; the week of the army is less than the measurement, and it is not taught.

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי הֶקְדֵּשׁ!
human_translation: Doesn’t consecrated
llm_translation: Behold, hekdesh!

hebrew_text: הָא בָּעֵינַן שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה.
human_translation: We require value of one peruta
llm_translation: This requires a similar coin.

hebrew_text: וְרַב אָשֵׁי מֵאַוֵּירְיָא אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: כִּי קָתָנֵי, זְדוֹנוֹ כָּרֵת; זְדוֹנוֹ לָאו, לָא קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: And Rav Ashi of Avireya said Rabbi Zeira When teaches intentional of karet , he does not teach prohibitions intentional of
llm_translation: And Rav Ashei from Avuveyra said, Rabbi Zeira said: When it is taught, intentional sin is excision; unintentional sin is not taught.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי אָשָׁם, דִּזְדוֹנוֹ לָאו, וְקָתָנֵי!
human_translation: But isn’t guilt-offering a prohibition which intentional of it And teaches
llm_translation: And behold, an Asham, his intentional sin is not, and the Mishnah teaches!

hebrew_text: בְּחַטָּאת קָאָמְרִינַן.
human_translation: We are speaking of sin-offerings
llm_translation: Regarding sin offering we are speaking.

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אָמַר: כִּי קָתָנֵי, מִידֵּי דְּחָיֵיל אַמִּידֵּי דְּבַר אֲכִילָה הוּא; שְׁבוּעָה דְּחָיְילָא אַמִּידֵּי דְּלָאו בַּר אֲכִילָה הוּא, לָא קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: Ravina said: When teaches those that apply to items that are edible. an oath, that applies to items that are not edible, does not teach
llm_translation: Ravina said: When it is taught, it is from the aspect of a soldier, and when it is not taught from the aspect of food; a soldier's oath is not taught.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי הֶקְדֵּשׁ – דְּחָיֵיל נָמֵי אַעֵצִים וַאֲבָנִים!
human_translation: But doesn’t consecrated which applies even to wood and stones?
llm_translation: And behold, the hekdesh - of valuable wood, cedars and stones!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא כִּי קָתָנֵי, מִידֵּי דְּחָיֵיל אַמִּידֵּי דְּאִית בֵּהּ מְשָׁשָׁא; שְׁבוּעָה דְּחָיְילָא אַמִּידֵּי דְּלֵית בֵּיהּ מְשָׁשָׁא, כְּגוֹן ״שֶׁאִישַׁן״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אִישַׁן״ – לָא קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: Rather, when teaches those that apply to tangible matters. an oath, that applies to intangible matters, such as: I will sleep, or: I will not sleep, does not teach
llm_translation: Rather, when it is taught, it is from the case of a soldier who has a weapon, as opposed to a soldier who does not have a weapon; the oath of a soldier who does not have a weapon, such as "that he has slept" and "that he has not slept" - it is not taught.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֶחָד דְּבָרִים שֶׁל עַצְמוֹ וְאֶחָד דְּבָרִים שֶׁל אֲחֵרִים, וְאֶחָד דְּבָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן מַמָּשׁ וְאֶחָד דְּבָרִים שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן מַמָּשׁ.
human_translation: both matters that concern oneself and matters that concern others, And both tangible matters and intangible matters.
llm_translation: It was taught: One case of a person causing harm to oneself, and one case of a person causing harm to others, and one case of matters involving actual damage, and one case of matters not involving actual damage.

hebrew_text: כֵּיצַד? אָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֶתֵּן לְאִישׁ פְּלוֹנִי״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶתֵּן״; ״שֶׁנָּתַתִּי״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא נָתַתִּי״;
human_translation: How so? said: oath I will give so-and-so or: I will not give I gave or: I did not give
llm_translation: "How so? He said, 'A vow that I give to a certain man,' and 'that I do not give'; 'that I have given,' and 'that I have not given.'"

hebrew_text: ״שֶׁאִישַׁן״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אִישַׁן״; ״שֶׁיָּשַׁנְתִּי״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא יָשַׁנְתִּי״; ״שֶׁאֶזְרוֹק צְרוֹר לַיָּם״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶזְרוֹק״; ״שֶׁזָּרַקְתִּי״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא זָרַקְתִּי״.
human_translation: I will sleep, or: I will not sleep. I slept, or: I did not sleep. I will throw a stone into the sea, or: I will not throw I threw or: I did not throw
llm_translation: "that he slept" and "that he did not sleep"; "that I slept" and "that I did not sleep"; "that I will cast a bundle into the sea" and "that I will not cast"; "that I cast" and "that I did not cast".

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא עַל הֶעָתִיד לָבֹא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael says: One is liable only about the future, as it is stated: to do evil, or to do good,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael says: He is not liable except for what is destined to come, as it is stated: "For evil or for good."

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: אִם כֵּן, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא דְּבָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה; דְּבָרִים שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה מִנַּיִן?
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva said to him: If so, I have only matters to which doing evil and doing good apply. From where matters to which doing evil and doing good do not apply?
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Akiva: If so, I have nothing but words that contain both evil and good; words that do not contain either evil or good, from where?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ: מֵרִיבּוּי הַכָּתוּב. אָמַר לוֹ: אִם רִיבָּה הַכָּתוּב לְכָךְ, רִיבָּה הַכָּתוּב לְכָךְ!
human_translation: said to him: by amplification of the verse. said to him: If the verse is amplified for this, the verse is amplified for that,
llm_translation: He said to him: From the contention of the Scripture. He said to him: If the Scripture contends for this, the Scripture contends for this!

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: חוֹמֶר בַּנְּדָרִים מִבַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת, חוֹמֶר בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת מִבַּנְּדָרִים. חוֹמֶר בַּנְּדָרִים – שֶׁהַנְּדָרִים חָלִים עַל דְּבַר מִצְוָה כִּדְבַר הָרְשׁוּת, מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת.
human_translation: the Sages taught: a stringency to vows to oaths, a stringency to oaths to vows. stringency to vows that vows take effect with regard to a matter a mitzva, like an optional matter, which is not the case with regard to oaths.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: A vow is more stringent than oaths, and oaths are more stringent than vows. More stringent are vows, for vows take effect regarding a matter of commandment as with a matter of permission, which is not the case with oaths.

hebrew_text: חוֹמֶר בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת – שֶׁהַשְּׁבוּעוֹת חָלוֹת עַל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַמָּשׁ כְּדָבָר שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מַמָּשׁ, מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בַּנְּדָרִים.
human_translation: stringency to oaths that oaths take effect with regard to an intangible matter like a tangible matter, which is not the case with regard to vows.
llm_translation: Material in oaths - that oaths take effect regarding something that has no substance like something that has substance, what is not so in vows.

hebrew_text: כֵּיצַד? אָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֶתֵּן לִפְלוֹנִי״ וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶתֵּן״. מַאי ״אֶתֵּן״? אִילֵּימָא צְדָקָה לְעָנִי, מוּשְׁבָּע וְעוֹמֵד מֵהַר סִינַי הוּא – שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״נָתוֹן תִּתֵּן לוֹ״!
human_translation: How so? said: oath I will give so-and-so or: I will not give What I will give? If we say charity to a poor person, he is under oath from Mount Sinai as it is stated “You shall give him”
llm_translation: How so? He said, "A vow that you give to so-and-so" and "that you do not give." What is "that you give"? If you say, charity to a poor person, one who has taken an oath and stands from Mount Sinai - as it says: "You shall surely give to him!"

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מַתָּנָה לְעָשִׁיר.
human_translation: Rather, a gift to a rich person.
llm_translation: Rather, a gift for the wealthy.

hebrew_text: ״שֶׁאִישַׁן״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אִישַׁן״ – אִינִי?! וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הָאוֹמֵר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אִישַׁן שְׁלֹשָׁה יָמִים״ – מַלְקִין אוֹתוֹ וְיָשֵׁן לְאַלְתַּר!
human_translation: I will sleep, or: I will not sleep, Is that so? But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say one who says: oath I will not sleep for three days, flogs him immediately and he may sleep.
llm_translation: "Shen ishan" and "shello ishan" - Is it not so?! And Rabbi Yochanan said: One who says, "An oath of not sleeping for three days" - he is lashed and should sleep immediately!

hebrew_text: הָתָם דְּאָמַר ״שְׁלֹשָׁה״, הָכָא דְּלָא אָמַר ״שְׁלֹשָׁה״.
human_translation: There, where he said three Here, where he did not say three
llm_translation: There, where it says "three," here it does not say "three."

hebrew_text: ״שֶׁאֶזְרוֹק צְרוֹר לַיָּם״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶזְרוֹק״. אִיתְּמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁזָּרַק פְּלוֹנִי צְרוֹר לַיָּם״ וְ״שֶׁלֹּא זָרַק״, רַב אָמַר חַיָּיב, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר פָּטוּר.
human_translation: I will throw a stone into the sea, or: I will not throw was stated: oath so-and-so threw a stone into the sea, or: oath he did not throw Rav says: liable And Shmuel says: exempt.
llm_translation: "The case of 'if one threw a bundle into the sea' and 'if one did not throw.' It was stated: 'If one swore that so-and-so threw a bundle into the sea' and 'if he did not throw,' Rav said liable, and Shmuel said exempt."

hebrew_text: רַב אָמַר חַיָּיב – אִיתֵיהּ בְּלָאו וְהֵן. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר פָּטוּר – לֵיתֵיהּ בִּלְהַבָּא.
human_translation: Rav says liable, can be positive or negative. And Shmuel says exempt, cannot be with regard to the future;
llm_translation: Rav said obligated - he has them with a negative and they. And Shmuel said exempt - he does not have them with a flame.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא בִּפְלוּגְתָּא דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא קָא מִיפַּלְגִי? דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא עַל הֶעָתִיד לָבֹא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: אִם כֵּן, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא דְּבָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה, דְּבָרִים שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה מִנַּיִן?
human_translation: Shall we say they disagree with regard to the dispute Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva? As we learned Rabbi Yishmael says: One is liable only about the future, as it is stated: to do evil, or to do good, Rabbi Akiva said to him: If so, I have only matters to which doing evil and doing good apply. From where matters to which doing evil and doing good do not apply?
llm_translation: Let us say in the dispute of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva, are they in disagreement? For we learned: Rabbi Yishmael says: One is liable only for what is destined to come, as it is stated: "For evil or for good." Rabbi Akiva said to him: If so, I have only matters that contain both evil and good, how do we know of matters that do not contain evil and good?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ: מֵרִיבּוּי הַכָּתוּב. אָמַר לוֹ: אִם רִיבָּה הַכָּתוּב לְכָךְ, רִיבָּה הַכָּתוּב לְכָךְ!
human_translation: said to him: by amplification of the verse. said to him: If the verse is amplified for this, the verse is amplified for that,
llm_translation: He said to him: From the repetition of the Scripture. He said to him: If the Scripture repeated it for this reason, the Scripture repeated it for this reason!

hebrew_text: רַב דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל?
human_translation: that Rav, states in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, And that Shmuel states in accordance with Rabbi Yishmael,
llm_translation: Rav said like Rabbi Akiva, and Shmuel said like Rabbi Yishmael?

hebrew_text: אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל – כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי; הַשְׁתָּא מִילְּתָא דְּאִיתַהּ בִּלְהַבָּא לָא מְחַיַּיב עֲלַהּ רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל לְשֶׁעָבַר, מִילְּתָא דְּלֵיתַהּ בִּלְהַבָּא מִיבַּעְיָא?!
human_translation: Everyone agrees according to of Rabbi Yishmael Now, a statement, that could be to the future, Rabbi Yishmael does not deem liable for it to the past. Is it necessary a statement, that cannot be to the future,
llm_translation: In the school of Rabbi Yishmael - everyone does not argue; now, a matter that has come up in the past, if it does not come up now, does Rabbi Yishmael require it?!

hebrew_text: כִּי פְּלִיגִי – אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא. רַב – כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא; וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: עַד כָּאן לָא מְחַיֵּיב רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הָתָם לְשֶׁעָבַר, אֶלָּא מִלְּתָא דְּאִיתַהּ בִּלְהַבָּא – מְחַיֵּיב רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא לְשֶׁעָבַר; אֲבָל מִידֵּי דְּלֵיתֵיהּ בִּלְהַבָּא – לָא.
human_translation: When they disagree, according to of Rabbi Akiva. Rav in accordance with Rabbi Akiva And Shmuel says: Rabbi Akiva deems one liable only there, to the past, a statement, that could be to the future; Rabbi Akiva deems one liable to the past, But statements that cannot to the future, not
llm_translation: When they argued - in the matter of Rabbi Akiva. Rav - like Rabbi Akiva; and Shmuel said: Up to here Rabbi Akiva does not obligate there for the past, but a matter that will come - Rabbi Akiva obligates for the past; but if it will not come - no.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא בִּפְלוּגְתָּא
human_translation: Shall we say the dispute
llm_translation: Let us say in the dispute.

hebrew_text: דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא וְרַבָּנַן קָמִיפַּלְגִי? דִּתְנַן: נִשְׁבַּע לְבַטֵּל אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא בִּיטֵּל – פָּטוּר. לְקַיֵּים אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא קִיֵּים – פָּטוּר. שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין שֶׁיְּהֵא חַיָּיב, כְּדִבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתִירָא; דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתִירָא: וּמָה אִם הָרְשׁוּת, שֶׁאֵינוֹ מוּשְׁבָּע עָלֶיהָ מֵהַר סִינַי – הֲרֵי הוּא חַיָּיב עָלֶיהָ; מִצְוָה, שֶׁמּוּשְׁבָּע עָלֶיהָ מֵהַר סִינַי – אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁיְּהֵא חַיָּיב עָלֶיהָ?
human_translation: disagreement Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira and the Rabbis? As we learned took an oath to refrain from a mitzva and he did not refrain, exempt to perform a mitzva and he did not perform exempt, though it would have been fitting that he is liable in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira. As Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said: What? If, an optional for which one is not under oath from Mount Sinai, he is liable for it, a mitzva, for which he is under oath from Mount Sinai, is it not logical that he would be liable for it?
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira and the Sages dispute? For it was taught: If one swears to annul a commandment and does not annul it - he is exempt. If one intends to fulfill a commandment and does not fulfill it - he is exempt. When it was a matter that he should be liable, according to the words of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira; for Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said: And what if it is a matter of permission, which was not sworn upon from Mount Sinai - behold, he is liable for it; a commandment, which was sworn upon from Mount Sinai - it is not a matter that he should be liable for it?

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: לֹא; אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּשְׁבוּעַת הָרְשׁוּת – שֶׁכֵּן עָשָׂה בָּהּ לָאו כְּהֵן; תֹּאמַר בִּשְׁבוּעַת מִצְוָה – שֶׁכֵּן לֹא עָשָׂה בָּהּ לָאו כְּהֵן?!
human_translation: said to him: No, if you said for an oath an optional where rendered a negative like a positive shall you say for an oath a mitzva, where did not render a negative like a positive
llm_translation: They said to him: No; if you say by an optional oath - that's how he acted with it, not like a priest; if you say by an obligatory oath - that's how he did not act with it, not like a priest?!

hebrew_text: נֵימָא רַב דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתִירָא, וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמַר כְּרַבָּנַן?
human_translation: Shall we say Rav states in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, and Shmuel states in accordance with the Rabbis,
llm_translation: Nayma, Rav said like Rabbi Yehuda ben Betera, and Shmuel said like Rabanan?

hebrew_text: אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתִירָא – כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי; הַשְׁתָּא לָאו וָהֵן לָא בָּעֵי, לְהַבָּא וּלְשֶׁעָבַר בָּעֵי?!
human_translation: Everyone, agrees with regard to of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira Now, does not require a negative a positive does he require to the future as well as to the past?
llm_translation: In the school of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira - the entire world does not argue; now, is it not the case that they do not want it, for the future do they want it?!

hebrew_text: כִּי פְּלִיגִי – אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבָּנַן. שְׁמוּאֵל – כְּרַבָּנַן; וְרַב – כִּי לָא מְחַיְּיבִי רַבָּנַן בְּלָאו וָהֵן, דִּכְתִיב ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ בְּהֶדְיָא; אֲבָל לְהַבָּא וּלְשֶׁעָבַר, דְּמֵרִיבּוּיָא דִּקְרָאֵי אָתוּ – מְחַיְּיבִי.
human_translation: When they disagree with regard to of the Rabbis: Shmuel like the Rabbis, And Rav the Rabbis do not deem one liable in negative positive as it is written explicitly: to do evil, or to do good” But to the future to the past which is derived from an amplification of the verses, deem one liable,
llm_translation: When they argue - according to the opinion of the Rabbis. Samuel - like the Rabbis; and Rav - because the Rabbis do not obligate with a negative commandment alone, as it is written "to do evil or to do good" with the hand; but for future and past actions, where the disputes of the verses come - they obligate.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב הַמְנוּנָא: ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי הַיּוֹם״ וְ״לֹא הִנַּחְתִּי תְּפִילִּין הַיּוֹם״; ״מַשְׁבִּיעֲךָ אֲנִי״, וְאָמַר ״אָמֵן״ – חַיָּיב. בִּשְׁלָמָא ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ – אִיתֵיהּ בְּ״לֹא אוֹכַל״; אֶלָּא ״לֹא הִנַּחְתִּי״ – מִי אִיתֵיהּ בְּ״לֹא אַנִּיחַ״?!
human_translation: Rav Hamnuna raises an objection I did not eat today, or: I did not don phylacteries today, I administer an oath to you and said: Amen, liable Granted, I did not eat, would have been possible I will not eat, but I did not don would it have been possible I will not don
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: "I did not eat today" and "I did not put on tefillin today"; "I adjure you," and he said "Amen" - he is liable. Granted, "I did not eat" - there is an alternative with "I did not eat"; but "I did not put on" - is there an alternative with "I did not put on"?!

hebrew_text: הוּא מוֹתֵיב לַהּ וְהוּא מְפָרֵק לַהּ – לִצְדָדִין קָתָנֵי: ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״ – לְקׇרְבָּן, ״לֹא הִנַּחְתִּי״ – לְמַלְקוֹת.
human_translation: He, raises the objection and he resolves it: teaches disjunctively, I did not eat, to an offering. I did not don to lashes
llm_translation: He sets her up and he breaks her down - the Tannaim on the side say: "I have not eaten" - for sacrifice, "I have not left" - for lashes.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רָבָא: אֵיזוֹ הִיא שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא? נִשְׁבַּע לְשַׁנּוֹת אֶת הַיָּדוּעַ לָאָדָם – וְאָמַר עַל עַמּוּד שֶׁל אֶבֶן שֶׁהוּא בְּמָקוֹם פְּלוֹנִי, שֶׁהוּא שֶׁל זָהָב. וְאָמַר עוּלָּא: וְהוּא שֶׁנִּיכָּר לִשְׁלֹשָׁה בְּנֵי אָדָם. טַעְמָא דְּנִיכָּר; הָא לֹא נִיכָּר – עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם שְׁבוּעַת בִּיטּוּי. וְאַמַּאי? הָא אֵינוֹ בִּ״יהֵא שֶׁל זָהָב״!
human_translation: Rava raises an objection Which is an oath in vain? takes an oath to deny that which is known to people and, says about a stone column that is in such and such a place that it is of gold. And Ulla says it is that is known to three people. The reason that known But not known, he violates of oath on an utterance. why Isn’t it impossible will be of gold?
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: What is an oath in vain? One swears to change something known to a person - and says about a pillar of stone that is in a certain place, that it is made of gold. And Ula said: And it is something that is recognizable to three people. The reason it is recognizable; if it is not recognizable - one transgresses due to a false oath. And why is that? Because it is not "a pillar of gold"!

hebrew_text: הוּא מוֹתֵיב לַהּ וְהוּא מְפָרֵק לַהּ: נִיכָּר – עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא, לֹא נִיכָּר – עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם שְׁבוּעַת שֶׁקֶר.
human_translation: He raises the objection and he resolves it. known violates of an oath in vain. not known, he violates of a false oath,
llm_translation: He establishes for her and he resolves for her: If it is recognizable - one transgresses due to a false oath, if it is not recognizable - one transgresses due to a false oath.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: וּמוֹדֶה רַב בְּאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֲנִי יוֹדֵעַ לְךָ עֵדוּת״, וְאִשְׁתְּכַח דְּלָא יְדַע לֵיהּ – דְּפָטוּר, הוֹאִיל וְלֵיתֵיהּ בִּכְלַל ״שֶׁאֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ לְךָ עֵדוּת״.
human_translation: Abaye said: And Rav, concedes where one says to another: oath I know testimony to you, and it is found that he did not know to him, that he is exempt that it is not in the category of I do not know testimony to you,
llm_translation: Abaye said: And Rav concedes by saying to his fellow, "I admit to you testimony," and it was found that he did not know it - he is exempt, since it is not included in "I do not admit to you testimony."

hebrew_text: ״יָדַעְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא יָדַעְתִּי״ – מַחְלוֹקֶת. ״הֵעַדְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא הֵעַדְתִּי״ – מַחְלוֹקֶת.
human_translation: I knew or: I did not know dispute I testified, or: I did not testify, dispute
llm_translation: "I knew" and "I did not know" - a dispute. "I testified" and "I did not testify" - a dispute.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לִשְׁמוּאֵל, דְּאָמַר: מִילְּתָא דְּלֵיתֵיהּ בִּלְהַבָּא לָא מְחַיֵּיב עֲלֵיהּ לְשֶׁעָבַר; לְהָכִי אַפְּקַהּ רַחֲמָנָא לִשְׁבוּעַת עֵדוּת מִכְּלַל שְׁבוּעַת בִּיטּוּי. אֶלָּא לְרַב, לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא אַפְּקַהּ רַחֲמָנָא?
human_translation: Granted, according to Shmuel, who says a matter that cannot to the future for which one is not liable to the past, for that the Merciful One removed an oath of testimony, from the category of an oath on an utterance But according to Rav, for what halakha did the Merciful One remove it
llm_translation: In truth, according to Shmuel, who said: A matter that does not involve a direct flame does not obligate one to bring a sin offering for a past act; therefore, the Merciful One established an oath for testimony as part of the general oath of denial. But according to Rav, for what purpose did the Merciful One establish it?

hebrew_text: אַמְרוּהָ רַבָּנַן קַמֵּיהּ דְּאַבָּיֵי: לְאִיחַיּוֹבֵי עֲלַיהּ תַּרְתֵּי.
human_translation: The Sages said before Abaye: to render liable two for it,
llm_translation: The sages said before Abaye: "To Ikhayovei upon her two."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ: תַּרְתֵּי לָא מָצִיתוּ אָמְרִיתוּ, דְּתַנְיָא: לְאַחַת מֵאֵלֶּה – לְאַחַת אַתָּה מְחַיְּיבוֹ, וְאִי אַתָּה מְחַיְּיבוֹ שְׁתַּיִם!
human_translation: said to them: You cannot say two as it is taught in one of these things” for one you may deem him liable, but you may not deem him liable two.
llm_translation: He said to them: Two did not find, you said, as it is taught: For one of these - for one you hold him liable, and if you do not hold him liable for one, you hold him liable for two!

hebrew_text: וּלְאַבָּיֵי, לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא אַפְּקָיהּ רַחֲמָנָא?
human_translation: And according to Abaye’s for what halakha did the Merciful One remove
llm_translation: And for Abbaye, regarding what matter did the Merciful One reveal it?

hebrew_text: לְכִדְתַנְיָא: בְּכוּלָּן נֶאֱמַר ״וְנֶעֱלַם״, וְכָאן לֹא נֶאֱמַר ״וְנֶעְלַם״; לְחַיֵּיב עַל הַמֵּזִיד כַּשּׁוֹגֵג.
human_translation: as it is taught For every is stated “And it is hidden and here, And it is hidden is not stated. to render liable for intentionally like unwittingly.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Lekidtanya: Bekhullan ne'emar 'vene'elam', ve'khan lo ne'emar 'vene'elam'; lechayyav al hamazid kashogeg." English translation: "It was taught in a Baraita: In all of them it is stated 'and it was hidden,' but here it is not stated 'and it was hidden'; to obligate for intentional sin like unintentional sin."

hebrew_text: אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ רַבָּנַן לְאַבָּיֵי: אֵימָא בְּמֵזִיד מִיחַיַּיב חֲדָא, בְּשׁוֹגֵג מִיחַיַּיב תַּרְתֵּי!
human_translation: The Sages said to Abaye: Say intentionally he is liable one unwittingly, he is liable two,
llm_translation: The scholars said to Abaye: "If one intentionally (commits a transgression), he is liable for one (sin offering), if unintentionally, he is liable for two!"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ: לָאו הַיְינוּ דַּאֲמַרִי – ״לְאַחַת״, אַחַת אַתָּה מְחַיְּיבוֹ וְאִי אַתָּה מְחַיְּיבוֹ שְׁתַּיִם; וְאִי בְּמֵזִיד, מִי אִיכָּא תַּרְתֵּי?
human_translation: said to them Is this not what they said in one of these for one you may deem him liable, but you may not deem him liable two? And if intentionally how could there be two
llm_translation: He said to them: Is this not what they said - "one"? One you obligate him, and if you do not obligate him, two; and if it was intentional, is there not two?

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: מִשּׁוּם דְּהָוֵה דָּבָר שֶׁבַּכְּלָל וְיָצָא לִידּוֹן בְּדָבָר הֶחָדָשׁ – אֵין לְךָ בּוֹ אֶלָּא חִידּוּשׁוֹ בִּלְבַד.
human_translation: Rava said Since is a matter that was in a generalization, and was singled out to teach a new matter with regard to it, you have only the new matter alone
llm_translation: Rava said: Because it is a matter that was included and went out to be judged in a new matter - you have in it only its novelty alone.

hebrew_text: מִכְּלַל דְּאַבָּיֵי סָבַר: אִיתַהּ לִשְׁבוּעָה בָּעוֹלָם?!
human_translation: by inference that Abaye holds the oath exists in principle?
llm_translation: From the principle of Abaye, he holds: Is there an oath in the world?!

hebrew_text: וְהָאָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מוֹדֶה רַב בְּאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֲנִי יוֹדֵעַ לָךְ עֵדוּת״, וְאִשְׁתְּכַח דְּלָא יְדַע לֵיהּ – דְּפָטוּר, הוֹאִיל וְלֵיתֵיהּ בְּאֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ לָךְ עֵדוּת!
human_translation: But didn’t Abaye say Rav concedes where one says to another: oath I know testimony to you, and it was found that he did not know to him? that exempt since it is not to I do not know testimony to you,
llm_translation: And Abaye said: Rav concedes when one says to his fellow, "I know testimony for you for a week," and it is found that he does not know it - he is exempt, since he does not actually know testimony for you for a week!

hebrew_text: הֲדַר בֵּיהּ אַבָּיֵי מֵהַהִיא. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא:
human_translation: Abaye retracted that And if you wish, say
llm_translation: "Glory to Abaye from that place. And if you will say..."

hebrew_text: חֲדָא מִינַּיְיהוּ רַב פָּפָּא אַמְרַהּ.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said one of those
llm_translation: One of them, Rav Papa, said it.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא עַל הֶעָתִיד לָבֹא. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – אֵין לִי אֶלָּא דְּבָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה; שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אוֹ נֶפֶשׁ כִּי תִשָּׁבַע לְבַטֵּא בִשְׂפָתַיִם״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael says: One is liable only about the future. The Sages taught to do evil, or to do good” I have only matters to which doing evil and doing good apply. From where matters to which doing evil and doing good do not apply? The verse states: “Or if anyone take an oath clearly with his lips,”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael says: One is only liable for what is destined to come. The Rabbis taught: "To do evil or to do good" - I have only words that contain both evil and good; how do we know that there are words that do not contain evil and good? The verse teaches: "Or a person who swears to pronounce with his lips."

hebrew_text: אֵין לִי אֶלָּא לְהַבָּא, לְשֶׁעָבַר מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְכֹל אֲשֶׁר יְבַטֵּא הָאָדָם בִּשְׁבֻעָה״. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא. רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – לְהַבָּא.
human_translation: I have only to the future. From where to the past? The verse states: “Whatsoever it be that a man shall utter clearly with an oath” the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yishmael says: “To do evil, or to do good,” about the future.
llm_translation: I have only to come, to pass from where? The Talmud teaches: "For all that a person expresses in an oath." The words of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yishmael says: "For harm or for good" - to come.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: אִם כֵּן, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא דְּבָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן הֲטָבָה וְהָרָעָה, דְּבָרִים שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה מִנַּיִן? אָמַר לוֹ: מֵרִבּוּי הַכָּתוּב. אָמַר לוֹ: אִם רִיבָּה הַכָּתוּב לְכָךְ, רִיבָּה הַכָּתוּב לְכָךְ!
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva said to him: If so, I have only matters to which doing evil and doing good apply. From where matters to which doing evil and doing good do not apply? said to from an amplification of the verse. said to him: If the verse is amplified for this, the verse is amplified for that,
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Akiva: If so, I have only things that have both good and bad in them, things that have neither bad nor good, from where? He said to him: From the abundance of the Scripture. He said to him: If the Scripture argued for this, the Scripture argued for this!

hebrew_text: שַׁפִּיר קָא אָמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא לְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל!
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva said well Rabbi Yishmael.
llm_translation: "Beautifully," said Rabbi Akiva to Rabbi Yishmael!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל – שֶׁשִּׁימֵּשׁ אֶת רַבִּי נְחוּנְיָא בֶּן הַקָּנָה, שֶׁהָיָה דּוֹרֵשׁ אֶת כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ בִּכְלָל וּפְרָט – אִיהוּ נָמֵי דּוֹרֵשׁ בִּכְלָל וּפְרָט. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא – שֶׁשִּׁימֵּשׁ אֶת נַחוּם אִישׁ גַּם זוֹ, שֶׁהָיָה דּוֹרֵשׁ אֶת כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ בְּרִיבָּה וּמִיעֵט – אִיהוּ נָמֵי דּוֹרֵשׁ רִיבָּה וּמִיעֵט.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Rabbi Yishmael who served Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana, who would interpret the entire Torah with a generalization and a detail. also interprets with a generalization and a detail. Rabbi Akiva who served Naḥum of Gam Zo, who would interpret the entire Torah with amplification and restriction. also interprets amplification and restriction.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Rabbi Yishmael - who used to engage with Rabbi Nechunia ben Hakanah, who would expound the entire Torah inclusively and exclusively - he too would expound inclusively and exclusively. Rabbi Akiva - who used to engage with Nachum Ish Gam Zo, who would expound the entire Torah expansively and restrictively - he too would expound expansively and restrictively.

hebrew_text: מַאי רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא דְּדָרֵישׁ רִיבּוּיֵי וּמִיעוּטֵי? דְּתַנְיָא: ״אוֹ נֶפֶשׁ כִּי תִשָּׁבַע״ – רִיבָּה, ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – מִיעֵט, ״לְכֹל אֲשֶׁר יְבַטֵּא הָאָדָם״ – חָזַר וְרִיבָּה; רִיבָּה וּמִיעֵט וְרִיבָּה – רִיבָּה הַכֹּל.
human_translation: What that Rabbi Akiva interprets amplifications and restrictions? as it is taught “Or if anyone take an oath amplifies “To do evil, or to do good,” restricts “Whatsoever it be that a man shall utter clearly then amplifies amplified, and restricted, and amplified, it amplified everything
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Akiva expounding on the terms of increase and decrease? For it was taught: "Or if a person swears" - this is an increase, "to do evil or to do good" - this is a decrease, "whatever a man may utter" - he reverts and increases; increase, decrease, and increase - increase encompasses all.

hebrew_text: מַאי רִיבָּה? רִיבָּה כֹּל מִילֵּי, וּמַאי מִיעֵט? מִיעֵט דְּבַר מִצְוָה.
human_translation: What amplified It amplified all matters And what restrict restricted a matter a mitzva,
llm_translation: What is "Ribah"? Ribah includes everything, and what is "Mi'et"? Mi'et is a matter of commandment.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל דָּרֵישׁ כְּלָל וּפְרָט: ״אוֹ נֶפֶשׁ כִּי תִשָּׁבַע לְבַטֵּא בִשְׂפָתַיִם״ – כְּלָל, ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – פְּרָט, ״לְכֹל אֲשֶׁר יְבַטֵּא הָאָדָם״ – חָזַר וְכָלַל; כְּלָל וּפְרָט וּכְלָל – אִי אַתָּה דָן אֶלָּא כְעֵין הַפְּרָט; מָה הַפְּרָט מְפוֹרָשׁ – לְהַבָּא, אַף כֹּל לְהַבָּא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael interprets a generalization and a detail: “Or if anyone take an oath clearly with his lips” a generalization; “to do evil, or to do good,” a detail; “whatsoever it be that a man shall utter clearly then generalized. a generalization, and a detail, and generalization, you may deduce only similar to the detail. Just as the detail explicitly to the future, so too, all to the future.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael expounded general and specific: "Or if a soul swears, pronouncing with his lips" - general, "to do evil or to do good" - specific, "whatever a man pronounces" - he repeated and included; general, specific, and general - you do not judge except according to the manner of the specific; just as the specific is explicit - for the future, so too all is for the future.

hebrew_text: אַהֲנִי כְּלָלָא, לְאֵתוֹיֵי אֲפִילּוּ דְּבָרִים שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה לְהַבָּא; אַהֲנִי פְּרָטָא, לְמַעוֹטֵי אֲפִילּוּ דְּבָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן הֲרָעָה וַהֲטָבָה לְשֶׁעָבַר.
human_translation: The generalization serves to include even matters that do not concern doing evil or doing good to the future; the detail serves to exclude even matters that concern doing evil or doing good to the past.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Ahani k'lala, l'etoyei apilu d'varim she'ein bahen hara'ah va'hatavah l'hava; ahani prat'a, l'ma'utei apilu d'varim she'yesh bahen hara'ah va'hatavah l'she'avar. English translation: It is a general principle, to include even things that have neither good nor bad consequences for the future; it is a specific principle, to exclude even things that have both good and bad consequences for the past.

hebrew_text: אֵיפוֹךְ אֲנָא!
human_translation: I will reverse
llm_translation: The opposite, I say!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: דּוּמְיָא דִּ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – מִי שֶׁאִיסּוּרוֹ מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״; יָצָאתָה זוֹ, שֶׁאֵין אִיסּוּרוֹ מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״, אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תְּשַׁקְּרוּ״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak said is similar to an oath “to do evil, or to do good” He whose prohibition is due to : “He shall not break his word” Excluded is that whose prohibition is not due to : “He shall not break his word”; rather, due to : “You shall not lie”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yitzchak said: "Similar to one who is for evil or for good" - one whose prohibition is due to 'do not profane My name'; this one has left, as his prohibition is not due to 'do not profane My name', but rather due to 'do not lie'.

hebrew_text: רַב יִצְחָק בַּר אָבִין אָמַר, אָמַר קְרָא: ״אוֹ נֶפֶשׁ כִּי תִשָּׁבַע לְבַטֵּא בִשְׂפָתַיִם״ – מִי שֶׁהַשְּׁבוּעָה קוֹדֶמֶת לַבִּיטּוּי, וְלֹא שֶׁהַבִּיטּוּי קוֹדֶמֶת לַשְּׁבוּעָה; יָצָא זֶה ״אָכַלְתִּי״ וְ״לֹא אָכַלְתִּי״, שֶׁהַמַּעֲשֶׂה קוֹדֵם לַשְּׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: Rav Yitzḥak bar Avin says The verse states: “Or if anyone take an oath clearly with his lips one whose oath precedes clarification, and not where the clarification, precedes the oath. Excluded is that I ate, or: I did not eat, where the action precedes the oath.
llm_translation: Rav Yitzchak bar Avin said, a verse states: "Or a soul that swears with his lips" - one whose oath precedes the expression, and not that the expression precedes the oath; this one is exempt for "I have eaten" and "I have not eaten," because the action precedes the oath.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״הָאָדָם בִּשְׁבוּעָה״ – פְּרָט לְאָנוּס. ״וְנֶעְלַם״ – פְּרָט לְמֵזִיד.
human_translation: The Sages taught “a man…with an oath” to exclude a victim of circumstances beyond his control “and it is hidden” to exclude intentionally,
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "A man under oath" - excluding cases of coercion. "And he conceals" - excluding cases of deliberate intent.

hebrew_text: ״מִמֶּנּוּ״ – שֶׁנִּתְעַלְּמָה מִמֶּנּוּ שְׁבוּעָה. יָכוֹל שֶׁנִּתְעַלְּמָה מִמֶּנּוּ חֵפֶץ? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בִּשְׁבוּעָה וְנֶעְלַם״ – עַל הֶעְלֵם שְׁבוּעָה הוּא חַיָּיב, וְאֵינוֹ חַיָּיב עַל הֶעְלֵם חֵפֶץ.
human_translation: “from him” one who was unaware of oath, might because he was unaware object the verse states: “With an oath, and it is hidden from him.” He is liable for lack of awareness of the oath but he is not liable for lack of awareness of the object
llm_translation: "From it" - that it disappeared from it a week. Can it be that it disappeared from it an object? The Talmud teaches: "In a week and it disappeared" - for the disappearance of a week one is liable, but one is not liable for the disappearance of an object.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: ״הָאָדָם בִּשְׁבוּעָה״ – פְּרָט לְאָנוּס. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי?
human_translation: The Master says “a man…with an oath” to exclude a victim of circumstances beyond his control. What are circumstances?
llm_translation: Master said: "A person under oath" - excluding cases of coercion. How so?

hebrew_text: כִּדְרַב כָּהֲנָא וְרַב אַסִּי, כִּי הֲווֹ קָיְימִי מִקַּמֵּי דְּרַב, מָר אֲמַר: שְׁבוּעֲתָא דְּהָכִי אֲמַר רַב, וּמָר אָמַר: שְׁבוּעֲתָא דְּהָכִי אֲמַר רַב. כִּי אֲתוֹ לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב, אֲמַר כְּחַד מִינַּיְיהוּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אִידַּךְ: וַאֲנָא בְּשִׁיקְרָא אִישְׁתְּבַעִי?!
human_translation: as with Rav Kahana and Rav Asi, when they were standing up in the presence of Rav, Sage said: oath Rav said like this, and Sage said: oath Rav said like that. When they came before Rav he stated in accordance with one of them The other said to Did I take a false oath?
llm_translation: As Rav Kahana and Rav Assi were sitting in front of Rav, the master said: "This is what Rav said in his oath," and the other master said: "This is what Rav said in his oath." When they came before Rav, he said to them: "One of you is lying." The other said to him: "And should I be suspected of lying?!"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לִבָּךְ אֲנָסָךְ.
human_translation: said to him: Your heart compelled you.
llm_translation: He said to him: Your heart coerces you.

hebrew_text: ״וְנֶעְלַם מִמֶּנּוּ״ – שֶׁנִּתְעַלֵּם מִמֶּנּוּ שְׁבוּעָה. יָכוֹל שֶׁנִּתְעַלֵּם מִמֶּנּוּ חֵפֶץ? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בִּשְׁבוּעָה וְנֶעְלַם מִמֶּנּוּ״ – עַל הֶעְלֵם שְׁבוּעָה הוּא חַיָּיב, וְאֵינוֹ חַיָּיב עַל הֶעְלֵם חֵפֶץ.
human_translation: “and it is hidden from him” one who was unaware of his oath, might because he was unaware object the verse states: “With an oath, and it is hidden from him.” He is liable for lack of awareness of the oath, but he is not liable for lack of awareness of the object
llm_translation: "And hidden from him" - that he concealed from him a week. Could it be that he concealed from him an object? The Talmud teaches: "In a week and hidden from him" - regarding the concealment of a week, one is liable, but one is not liable for the concealment of an object.

hebrew_text: מַחֲכוּ עֲלֵיהּ בְּמַעְרְבָא: בִּשְׁלָמָא שְׁבוּעָה – מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ בְּלָא חֵפֶץ, כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל פַּת חִטִּין״, וּכְסָבוּר ״שֶׁאוֹכַל״ קָאָמַר – דִּשְׁבוּעֲתֵיהּ אִינְּשִׁי, חֶפְצָא דְּכִיר; אֶלָּא חֵפֶץ בְּלֹא שְׁבוּעָה, הֵיכִי דָּמֵי?
human_translation: They laughed at this in the West, Granted, you find oath without the object where one said: oath I will not eat wheat bread, and he thought he had said: I will eat as his oath is forgotten the object is remembered. But what circumstances the object without oath
llm_translation: Wait for it in the evening: Regarding an oath - she forgets it without desire, for example, when he said: "An oath not to eat wheat bread," and he thought that he meant "to eat" - his oath is considered as if it is a person, a known object; but without an oath, how is it comparable?

hebrew_text: כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל פַּת חִטִּין״, וּכְסָבוּר ״שֶׁל שְׂעוֹרִים״ קָאָמַר – דִּשְׁבוּעֲתֵיהּ דְּכִיר לֵיהּ, חֶפְצָא אִינְּשִׁי. כֵּיוָן דְּחֶפְצָא אִינְּשִׁי לְהוּ, הַיְינוּ הֶעְלֵם שְׁבוּעָה!
human_translation: where he said: oath I will not eat wheat bread, and he thought he had said: barley as his oath is remembered by him the object is forgotten. Once the object is forgotten by him, that is lack of awareness of his oath.
llm_translation: For example, he said: "An oath not to eat wheat bread," and he thinks "of barley" he meant - because his oath is dear to him, people's desires. Since people's desires are important to him, that is an annulment of an oath!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: דָּא וְדָא אַחַת הִיא.
human_translation: Rather, Rabbi Elazar said: this and that are one
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Elazar said: This and that are one and the same.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב יוֹסֵף: אַלְמָא חֵפֶץ בְּלֹא שְׁבוּעָה לָא מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ? וְהָא מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ – כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל פַּת חִטִּין״, וְהוֹשִׁיט יָדוֹ לַסַּל לִיטּוֹל פַּת שְׂעוֹרִין; וְעָלְתָה בְּיָדוֹ שֶׁל חִטִּין, וּכְסָבוּר שְׂעוֹרִים הִיא וַאֲכָלָהּ; דִּשְׁבוּעֲתֵיהּ דְּכִיר לֵיהּ, חֶפְצָא הוּא דְּלָא יָדַע לֵיהּ!
human_translation: Rav Yosef objects to this. really you do not find the object without oath? But you find where he said: oath I will not eat wheat bread, and he extended his hand to the basket to take barley bread, and wheat came up in his hand, and he thought it was barley and ate it. where his oath is remembered by him, and it is the object of which he is unaware.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef objects to her: If she desires without a vow, does she not forget it? And she forgets it - for example, if she said, "I vow not to eat wheat bread," and she extends her hand to the basket to take barley bread, and wheat bread comes into her hand, and she thinks it is barley and eats it; her vow is not in her mind, for it is something she did not know!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: כְּלוּם מְחַיְּיבַתְּ לֵיהּ קׇרְבָּן – אֶלָּא אַמַּאי דִּתְפִיס בִּידֵיהּ; הֶעְלֵם שְׁבוּעָה הוּא!
human_translation: Abaye said to him: Don’t you deem him liable an offering only for that which he holds in his hand is lack of awareness of the oath,
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: If she is not obligated to bring a sacrifice - then why does she grasp it in her hands; it is a hidden oath!

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא – אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי לְרַב יוֹסֵף: סוֹף סוֹף, קׇרְבָּן דְּקָא מַיְיתֵי עֲלַהּ דְּהַאי פַּת מִיהַת, הֶעְלֵם שְׁבוּעָה הוּא!
human_translation: another formulation Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Ultimately, the offering he brings for this bread is in any event lack of awareness of the oath,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Lishana achreina - amar lei Abaye le'Rav Yosef: Sof sof, korban deka maytei alah dehai pat miheitei, he'elem shvuah hu!" English translation: "Another version - Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Ultimately, the offering that comes for this bread is a hidden oath!"

hebrew_text: וְרַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר לָךְ: כֵּיוָן דְּכִי יָדַע לֵיהּ דְּחִטִּין הוּא – פָּרֵישׁ מִינֵּיהּ, הֶעְלֵם חֵפֶץ הוּא.
human_translation: And Rav Yosef say to you: Since were he to know of it that it is wheat he would refrain from it, lack of awareness of the object.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said to her: Since he knew that he is wheat - he separated from her, it is a hidden desire.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבָא מֵרַב נַחְמָן: הֶעְלֵם זֶה וְזֶה בְּיָדוֹ, מַהוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הֲרֵי הֶעְלֵם שְׁבוּעָה בְּיָדוֹ, וְחַיָּיב. אַדְּרַבָּה, הֲרֵי הֶעְלֵם חֵפֶץ בְּיָדוֹ, וּפָטוּר!
human_translation: Rava asked of Rav Naḥman: has a lack of awareness of this, and that, what is said to him: He having a lack of awareness of the oath and liable. On the contrary, he has a lack of awareness of the object and exempt.
llm_translation: Rava asked a question of Rav Nachman: If one conceals both this and that in his hand, what is the ruling? He said to him: If he conceals a pledge in his hand, he is liable. But if he conceals an object in his hand, he is exempt!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: חָזֵינַן; אִי מֵחֲמַת שְׁבוּעָה קָא פָרֵישׁ – הֲרֵי הֶעְלֵם שְׁבוּעָה בְּיָדוֹ, וְחַיָּיב; אִי מֵחֲמַת חֵפֶץ קָא פָרֵישׁ – הֲרֵי הֶעְלֵם חֵפֶץ בְּיָדוֹ, וּפָטוּר.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: We see: If he refrains due to the oath, he had a lack of awareness of the oath and is liable. If he refrains due to the object he had a lack of awareness due to the object, and is exempt.
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said: We have seen; if he separated due to an oath - behold, he has the concealment of the oath in his hand, and he is liable; if he separated due to desire - behold, he has the concealment of desire in his hand, and he is exempt.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: כְּלוּם פָּרֵישׁ מִשְּׁבוּעָה – אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם חֵפֶץ! כְּלוּם פָּרֵישׁ מֵחֵפֶץ – אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם שְׁבוּעָה! אֶלָּא לָא שְׁנָא.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Doesn’t he refrain only from oath due to object? Doesn’t he refrain from object due only to oath? Rather, there is no difference
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: "If he separated from the oath - rather due to desire! If he did not separate from desire - rather due to the oath! But it is not different."

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבָא מֵרַב נַחְמָן:
human_translation: Rava asked of Rav Naḥman:
llm_translation: Requested from him Rava from Rav Nachman:

hebrew_text: אֵיזוֹ הִיא שִׁגְגַת שְׁבוּעַת בִּיטּוּי לְשֶׁעָבַר? אִי דְּיָדַע – מֵזִיד הוּא! אִי דְּלָא יָדַע – אָנוּס הוּא!
human_translation: What is an unwitting oath on an utterance to the past, If where he knows he is an intentional If where he did not know he is a victim of circumstances beyond his control,
llm_translation: Which is the inadvertent transgression of an oath through expression for the past? If he knew - it is intentional! If he did not know - it is coerced!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, בְּאוֹמֵר: ״יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁשְּׁבוּעָה זוֹ אֲסוּרָה, אֲבָל אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ אִם חַיָּיבִין עָלֶיהָ קׇרְבָּן אוֹ לָאו״.
human_translation: said to him where says: I know that this oath is prohibited, but I do not know if one is liable an offering for it or not.
llm_translation: He said to him, in saying: "I know that this week is forbidden, but I do not know if one is obligated to bring a sacrifice for it or not."

hebrew_text: כְּמַאן – כְּמוֹנְבַּז, דְּאָמַר: שִׁגְגַת קׇרְבָּן שְׁמָהּ שְׁגָגָה?
human_translation: In accordance with whose in accordance with Munbaz, who says: Lack of intention with regard to the offering, is regarded as lack of intention?
llm_translation: As whom - as Monbaz, who said: "The unintentional sin of an offering, its name is unintentional?"

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבָּנַן, עַד כָּאן לָא פְּלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ דְּמוֹנְבַּז – אֶלָּא בְּכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ, דְּלָאו חִידּוּשׁ הוּא; אֲבָל הָכָא, דְּחִידּוּשׁ הוּא – דִּבְכָל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ לָא אַשְׁכְּחַן לָאו דְּמַיְיתֵי קׇרְבָּן,
human_translation: You even say the Rabbis. The Rabbis disagree with of Munbaz only with regard to all the entire Torah is not a novelty. But here, that is a novelty, since we do not find in the entire Torah prohibition for which brings an offering
llm_translation: Even if you say it is the view of the Rabbis, up to this point the Rabbis do not disagree with it regarding the case of Monbaz - rather, in the entire Torah, since it is not a novelty; but here, since it is a novelty - because in the entire Torah we do not find a case similar to the offering.

hebrew_text: דְּיָלְפִינַן מֵעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה; וְהָכָא מַיְיתֵי – אֲפִילּוּ רַבָּנַן מוֹדוּ.
human_translation: that we derive from idol worship, And here, one brings even the Rabbis would agree
llm_translation: We separate from foreign worship; and here it comes - even the Rabbis agree.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבִינָא מֵרָבָא: נִשְׁבַּע עַל כִּכָּר וּמִסְתַּכֵּן עָלֶיהָ, מַהוּ?
human_translation: Ravina asked Rava: took an oath concerning loaf, and is in danger what is
llm_translation: Requested of him Ravina from Rava: He swore upon a loaf and leaned upon it, what is the ruling?

hebrew_text: מִסְתַּכֵּן – לִישְׁרֵי לֵיהּ מָר! אֶלָּא מִצְטַעֵר, וַאֲכָלָהּ בְּשִׁגְגַת שְׁבוּעָה – מַאי?
human_translation: in danger, let the Master permit him Rather, one who is suffering and ate it unwittingly, oath, what
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: "Mistaken - to straighten it, Master! Rather, it is a mistake, and she ate it unintentionally during the week of her impurity - what is the ruling?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, תְּנֵינָא: שָׁב מִידִיעָתוֹ – מֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן עַל שִׁגְגָתוֹ; לֹא שָׁב מִידִיעָתוֹ – אֵין מֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן עַל שִׁגְגָתוֹ.
human_translation: to him: We learn One withdrawn due to his knowledge, brings an offering for his unwitting one would not have withdrawn due to his knowledge does not bring an offering for his unwitting
llm_translation: He said to him, we learn: If one repents immediately upon realizing his sin - he brings a sacrifice for his unintentional transgression; if he does not repent immediately upon realizing his sin - he does not bring a sacrifice for his unintentional transgression.

hebrew_text: אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: גָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ – צָרִיךְ שֶׁיּוֹצִיא בִּשְׂפָתָיו; שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לְבַטֵּא בִּשְׂפָתַיִם״.
human_translation: Shmuel says: decided needs to express with his lips as it is stated clearly with his lips
llm_translation: Samuel said: One who completes in his heart - he must express with his lips; as it is stated: "To articulate with the lips."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״בִּשְׂפָתַיִם״ – וְלֹא בַּלֵּב; גָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְכֹל אֲשֶׁר יְבַטֵּא הָאָדָם בִּשְׁבוּעָה״.
human_translation: raises an objection “with his lips,” but not with his heart. From where one who decided in his heart The verse states: “Whatsoever it be that a man shall express with an oath”
llm_translation: Challenger: "With lips" - and not with heart; he completes in his heart, from where? Scripture teaches: "For every matter of an oath that a man may utter."

hebrew_text: הָא גּוּפַהּ קַשְׁיָא – אָמְרַתְּ ״בִּשְׂפָתַיִם״ וְלֹא בַּלֵּב, וַהֲדַר אָמְרַתְּ ״גָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ מִנַּיִן״?!
human_translation: This difficult itself. You said: “With his lips,” but not with his heart, and then you said: From where one who decided in his heart
llm_translation: The body itself is difficult - you said "with the lips" and not with the heart, and then you said "he completed it in his heart, from where?!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: הָא לָא קַשְׁיָא; הָכִי קָאָמַר: ״בִּשְׂפָתַיִם״ – וְלֹא שֶׁגָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ לְהוֹצִיא בִּשְׂפָתָיו וְלֹא הוֹצִיא; גָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ סְתָם מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְכֹל אֲשֶׁר יְבַטֵּא״.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet said: This not difficult; this is saying: “with his lips” and not when he decided in his heart to express with his lips but has not expressed From where simply decided in his heart The verse states: “Whatsoever it be that shall express
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet said: This is not difficult; thus he said: "with his lips" - and not that he completed in his heart to bring out with his lips and did not bring out; if he completed in his heart, how do we know that it is considered as if he spoke? The Torah teaches: "for all that he expresses."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לִשְׁמוּאֵל קַשְׁיָא!
human_translation: But according to Shmuel, a difficulty,
llm_translation: To Shmuel it is difficult!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת, תָּרֵיץ וְאֵימָא הָכִי: ״בִּשְׂפָתַיִם״ – וְלֹא שֶׁגָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ לְהוֹצִיא ״פַּת חִטִּין״ וְהוֹצִיא ״פַּת שְׂעוֹרִין״; גָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ לְהוֹצִיא ״פַּת חִטִּין״ וְהוֹצִיא ״פַּת״ סְתָם, מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְכֹל אֲשֶׁר יְבַטֵּא הָאָדָם״.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet said: Resolve and say this: “with his lips,” but not where he decided in his heart to express wheat bread and expressed barley bread. From where he decided in his heart to express wheat bread and expressed bread without specifying? The verse states: “Whatsoever it be that shall express
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet said, let him resolve it and say thus: "with his lips" - and not that he intended in his heart to bring out "a loaf of wheat" and he brought out "a loaf of barley"; if he intended in his heart to bring out "a loaf of wheat" and he brought out a plain "loaf," from where? The Talmud teaches: "for all that a man shall express."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״מוֹצָא שְׂפָתֶיךָ תִּשְׁמוֹר וְעָשִׂיתָ״ – אֵין לִי אֶלָּא שֶׁהוֹצִיא בִּשְׂפָתָיו; גָּמַר בְּלִבּוֹ מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כׇּל נְדִיב לֵב״!
human_translation: raises an objection “That which is gone out of your lips you shall observe and do; I have only which he expresses with his lips. From where he decided in his heart? The verse states as many as were willinghearted,
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: A question was raised: "That which has gone out of your lips you shall observe and do" - I only have that which he uttered with his lips; how do I know that he completed it in his heart? The teaching states: "Every generous heart!"

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דִּכְתִיב ״כׇּל נְדִיב לֵב״.
human_translation: there, is different, as it is written: “As many as were willinghearted.”
llm_translation: The matter is different there, for it is written, "Every generous heart."

hebrew_text: וְנִיגְמַר מִינַּהּ!
human_translation: And let us learn from it
llm_translation: And it was concluded from it!

hebrew_text: מִשּׁוּם דְּהָווּ תְּרוּמָה וְקָדָשִׁים שְׁנֵי כְּתוּבִין הַבָּאִין כְּאֶחָד, וְכׇל שְׁנֵי כְּתוּבִין הַבָּאִין כְּאֶחָד אֵין מְלַמְּדִין.
human_translation: because teruma , and consecrated are two verses that come as one, and any two verses that come as one do not teach
llm_translation: Because there were Terumah and Kodshim, two Scriptures that come as one, and any two Scriptures that come as one do not teach.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר אֵין מְלַמְּדִין, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מְלַמְּדִין – מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: This works out well according to the one who says do not teach but according to the one who says they do teach what can be said?
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates to: "He left it for the one who says we do not teach, but for the one who says we do teach - what can be said?"

hebrew_text: הָווּ חוּלִּין וְקָדָשִׁים, וְחוּלִּין מִקֳּדָשִׁים לָא גָּמְרִינַן.
human_translation: non-sacred and consecrated and we do not derive non-sacred from consecrated
llm_translation: They were mundane and holy, and mundane does not complete holy.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נִשְׁבַּע לְבַטֵּל אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא בִּיטֵּל – פָּטוּר. לְקַיֵּים וְלֹא קִיֵּים – פָּטוּר; שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין שֶׁיְּהֵא חַיָּיב, כְּדִבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא.
human_translation: takes an oath to refrain from a mitzva and he does not refrain, exempt to perform and he does not perform exempt, though it would have been fitting that he is liable in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If one swears to annul a commandment and does not annul it - he is exempt. If he intends to fulfill it and does not fulfill it - he is exempt; because he was in a situation where he should have been liable, according to the words of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא: מָה אִם הָרְשׁוּת, שֶׁאֵינוֹ מוּשְׁבָּע עָלָיו מֵהַר סִינַי – הֲרֵי הוּא חַיָּיב עָלָיו; מִצְוָה, שֶׁהוּא מוּשְׁבָּע עָלֶיהָ מֵהַר סִינַי – אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁיְּהֵא חַיָּיב עָלֶיהָ?!
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said: What? If, an optional for which one is not under oath from Mount Sinai, he is liable for it, a mitzva, for which he is under oath from Mount Sinai, is it not logical that he would be liable for it?
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Betera said: What if one transgresses a prohibition that was not sworn upon him from Mount Sinai - behold, he is liable for it; but a commandment that was sworn upon him from Mount Sinai - is it not fitting that he should be liable for it?!

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: לֹא אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּשְׁבוּעַת הָרְשׁוּת – שֶׁכֵּן עָשָׂה בָּהּ לָאו כְּהֵן, תֹּאמַר בִּשְׁבוּעַת מִצְוָה – שֶׁלֹּא עָשָׂה בָּהּ לָאו כְּהֵן; שֶׁאִם נִשְׁבַּע לְבַטֵּל וְלֹא בִּיטֵּל – פָּטוּר.
human_translation: said to him: No, if you said for an oath an optional where rendered a negative like a positive shall you say with regard to an oath a mitzva, where did not render a negative like a positive since if one takes an oath to refrain a mitzva and did not refrain, exempt.
llm_translation: They said to him: If you said in a voluntary oath - that is how he acted with it, not like a priest, you should say in a mandatory oath - that he did not act with it like a priest; for if he swore to annul and did not annul - he is exempt.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: יָכוֹל נִשְׁבַּע לְבַטֵּל אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא בִּיטֵּל, יְהֵא חַיָּיב? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – מָה הֲטָבָה רְשׁוּת, אַף הֲרָעָה רְשׁוּת; אוֹצִיא נִשְׁבַּע לְבַטֵּל אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא בִּיטֵּל, שֶׁהוּא פָּטוּר.
human_translation: The Sages taught might one takes an oath to refrain a mitzva and he does not refrain, he would be liable the verse states: “To do evil, or to do good” Just as doing good an optional so too, doing evil an optional I will exclude takes an oath to refrain from a mitzva and does not refrain, that he is exempt
llm_translation: The Sages taught: Can one swear to annul a commandment and not annul it, should he be liable? The verse teaches: "to do evil or to do good" - just as doing good is optional, so too doing evil is optional; therefore, one who swears to annul a commandment and does not annul it, is exempt.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל נִשְׁבַּע לְקַיֵּים אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא קִיֵּים, שֶׁיְּהֵא חַיָּיב? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – מָה הֲרָעָה רְשׁוּת, אַף הֲטָבָה רְשׁוּת; אוֹצִיא נִשְׁבַּע לְקַיֵּים אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא קִיֵּים, שֶׁהוּא פָּטוּר.
human_translation: might one takes an oath to perform a mitzva and does not perform that he would be liable. the verse states: “To do evil, or to do good.” Just as doing evil an optional so too, doing good an optional I will exclude takes an oath to perform a mitzva and does not perform that he is exempt
llm_translation: One might have thought that if one swears to fulfill a commandment and does not fulfill it, they should be liable. The Talmud teaches: "to do evil or to do good" - just as doing evil is optional, so too doing good is optional. Therefore, if one swears to fulfill a commandment and does not fulfill it, they are exempt.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל נִשְׁבַּע לְהָרַע לְעַצְמוֹ וְלֹא הָרַע – יָכוֹל יְהֵא פָּטוּר? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – מָה הֲטָבָה רְשׁוּת, אַף הֲרָעָה רְשׁוּת; אָבִיא נִשְׁבַּע לְהָרַע לְעַצְמוֹ וְלֹא הֵרַע, שֶׁהָרְשׁוּת בְּיָדוֹ.
human_translation: might one takes an oath to harm himself and he does not harm himself, that he could be exempt The verse states: “To do evil, or to do good.” Just as doing good an optional so too, doing evil an optional I include one takes an oath to harm himself and does not harm since is his prerogative
llm_translation: One could swear to harm oneself and not harm - can one be exempt? The verse says: "to do evil or to do good" - just as doing good is optional, so too doing evil is optional; I will bring a case of one who swears to harm himself and does not harm, for the choice is in his hands.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל נִשְׁבַּע לְהָרַע לַאֲחֵרִים וְלֹא הֵרַע, שֶׁיְּהֵא חַיָּיב? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״ – מָה הֲטָבָה רְשׁוּת, אַף הֲרָעָה רְשׁוּת; אוֹצִיא נִשְׁבַּע לְהָרַע לַאֲחֵרִים וְלֹא הֵרַע, שֶׁאֵין הָרְשׁוּת בְּיָדוֹ. מִנַּיִן לְרַבּוֹת הֲטָבַת אֲחֵרִים? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״. וְאֵיזוֹ הִיא הֲרָעַת אֲחֵרִים? ״אַכֶּה אֶת פְּלוֹנִי וַאֲפַצֵּעַ אֶת מוֹחוֹ״.
human_translation: might one takes an oath to harm others and does not harm that he would be liable. the verse states: “To do evil, or to do good.” Just as doing good an optional so too, doing evil an optional I will exclude one who takes an oath to harm others and he does not harm since is not his prerogative From where doing good to others is included The verse states: “Or to do good.” And what is harming others? I will strike so-and-so and injure his brain.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Can one swear to harm others and not fulfill it, so that he should be liable? The Torah teaches: "to harm or to benefit" - just as benefiting is optional, so too harming is optional. If one swears to harm others and does not fulfill it, it is because the authority is not in his hands. How do we know to include benefiting others? The Torah teaches: "or to benefit." And what is harming others? "I will strike so-and-so and cause his brain to splatter."

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דִּקְרָאֵי בִּדְבַר הָרְשׁוּת כְּתִיבִי? דִּלְמָא בִּדְבַר מִצְוָה כְּתִיבִי!
human_translation: But from where that verses are written to optional matters? Perhaps are written to matters a mitzva.
llm_translation: And from where do we derive that the verses regarding matters of permission are written? Perhaps they are written regarding matters of obligation!

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ; דְּבָעֵינַן הֲטָבָה דּוּמְיָא דַּהֲרָעָה, וַהֲרָעָה דּוּמְיָא דַּהֲטָבָה; דְּאַקֵּישׁ הֲרָעָה לַהֲטָבָה – מָה הֲטָבָה אֵינָהּ בְּבִיטּוּל מִצְוָה, אַף הֲרָעָה אֵינָהּ בְּבִיטּוּל מִצְוָה. הֲרָעָה גּוּפָהּ – הֲטָבָה הִיא.
human_translation: should not enter your mind, since we require doing good similar to doing evil, and doing evil similar to doing good, as doing evil is juxtaposed to doing good then just as doing good does not refraining from a mitzva, so too, doing evil does not refraining from a mitzva, doing evil is itself doing good,
llm_translation: It is not as you think; for we require the likeness of good to evil, and the likeness of evil to good; for the evil is compared to the good - just as the good is not through the nullification of a commandment, so too the evil is not through the nullification of a commandment. Evil itself is good.

hebrew_text: וְאַקֵּישׁ הֲטָבָה לַהֲרָעָה – מָה הֲרָעָה אֵינָהּ בְּקִיּוּם מִצְוָה, אַף הֲטָבָה אֵינָהּ בְּקִיּוּם מִצְוָה. הֲטָבָה גּוּפַהּ – הֲרָעָה הִיא.
human_translation: And doing good is juxtaposed to doing evil; just as doing evil does not performing a mitzva, so too, doing good does not performing a mitzva. Doing good is itself doing evil,
llm_translation: "And I will compare good to evil - just as evil is not in the fulfillment of a commandment, so too good is not in the fulfillment of a commandment. Good itself is evil."

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, בִּדְבַר הָרְשׁוּת נָמֵי לָא מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ!
human_translation: If that is so, you do not find even with regard to optional matters,
llm_translation: If so, in a matter of permission alone, you do not forget her!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מִדְּאִיצְטְרִיךְ ״אוֹ״ לְרַבּוֹת הֲטָבַת אֲחֵרִים – שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ בִּדְבַר הָרְשׁוּת כְּתִיבִי. דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בִּדְבַר מִצְוָה כְּתִיבִי; הַשְׁתָּא הֲרָעַת אֲחֵרִים אִיתְרַבַּי, הֲטָבַת אֲחֵרִים מִיבַּעְיָא?!
human_translation: Rather, from that it was necessary “or to include doing good to others. Conclude from it verses are written to optional matters. As, if it should enter your mind verses are written to matters a mitzva, Now doing evil to others has been included, is necessary doing good to others?
llm_translation: Rather, since the word "or" is necessary to include the benefit of others - infer from it in matters of permission as it is written. For if your intention was in matters of commandment, it is written; if the harm of others has increased, does the benefit of others come about?!

hebrew_text: וְהַאי ״אוֹ״ – מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְחַלֵּק! לְחַלֵּק לָא צְרִיךְ קְרָא.
human_translation: But this “or” is necessary to separate A verse is unnecessary to separate,
llm_translation: And this "or" - it is needed to divide! To divide does not need a verse.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְרַבִּי יוֹנָתָן, אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: This works out well according to Rabbi Yonatan’s but according to Rabbi Yoshiya’s what can be said?
llm_translation: He left it for Rabbi Yonatan, rather for Rabbi Yoshiyah, what is there to say?

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: ״אִישׁ אֲשֶׁר יְקַלֵּל אֶת אָבִיו וְאֶת אִמּוֹ״ – אֵין לִי אֶלָּא אָבִיו וְאִמּוֹ; אָבִיו וְלֹא אִמּוֹ, אִמּוֹ וְלֹא אָבִיו – מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אָבִיו וְאִמּוֹ קִלֵּל״ – אָבִיו קִלֵּל, אִמּוֹ קִלֵּל. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה.
human_translation: As it is taught “A man who curses his father and his mother I have only his father and his mother. From where his father but not his mother, his mother but not his father, the verse states: “His father and his mother he has cursed; he cursed his father he cursed his mother; the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "He who curses his father or his mother" - I have only his father and his mother; his father and not his mother, his mother and not his father - from where? The Talmud teaches: "His father and his mother he cursed" - he cursed his father, he cursed his mother. These are the words of Rabbi Yoshiyah.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן אוֹמֵר: מַשְׁמָע שְׁנֵיהֶם כְּאֶחָד וּמַשְׁמָע אֶחָד בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ,
human_translation: Rabbi Yonatan says: indicates both of them together, and it indicates one on their own,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yonatan says: Hear both of them as one, and hear one by itself.

hebrew_text: עַד שֶׁיִּפְרוֹט לְךָ הַכָּתוּב ״יַחְדָּיו״.
human_translation: unless the verse specifies together.
llm_translation: Until the verse "yachdav" is explained to you.

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה; וְסָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא דְּדָרֵישׁ רִבּוּיֵי וּמִיעוּטֵי, וְאִיַּיתַּר לֵיהּ ״אוֹ״ לְחַלֵּק.
human_translation: You even say Rabbi Yoshiya. holds in accordance with Rabbi Akiva, who interprets amplifications and restrictions and “or” is superfluous to separate
llm_translation: Even if you say it is Rabbi Yoshiyah; and he holds like Rabbi Akiva who expounds on the inclusive and exclusive, and he brings the "or" to divide.

hebrew_text: אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא בִּדְבַר הָרְשׁוּת כְּתִיב, מְמַעֵט דְּבַר מִצְוָה; אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּדְבַר מִצְוָה כְּתִיב, מִמַּאי קָא מְמַעֵט?
human_translation: Granted, if you say is written with regard to optional matters, restrict a matter a mitzva. But if you say is written to a matter a mitzva, what restrict?
llm_translation: If you say it is written regarding a matter of permission, "from a small matter of a commandment," but if you say it is written regarding a matter of commandment, from what is it diminishing?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא: מָה אִם הָרְשׁוּת כּוּ׳. וְרַבָּנַן – שַׁפִּיר קָאָמְרִי לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא!
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said: What? If, an optional The Rabbis’ to Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira is well stated.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said: "What if the permission is like this?" And the Rabbis said: "Well said to Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira!"

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא אָמַר לָךְ: אַטּוּ הֲטָבַת אֲחֵרִים – לָאו אַף עַל גַּב דְּלֵיתַהּ בִּכְלַל הֲרָעַת אֲחֵרִים, וְרַבִּי רַחֲמָנָא? הָכָא נָמֵי בְּקִיּוּם מִצְוָה – אַף עַל גַּב דְּלֵיתֵיהּ בְּבִיטּוּל מִצְוָה, רַבְּיֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira say to you: Isn’t doing good to others, even though it does not include harming others, but the Merciful One has amplified Here also, with regard to perform a mitzva, even though does not refraining from a mitzva, the Merciful One has amplified
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Betera said to you: If you have benefited others - it is not even though you have not included harming others, and Rabbi Rachmana? Here too in fulfilling a commandment - even though you have not included in nullifying a commandment, the Merciful One will have mercy.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן – הָתָם, אִיתֵיהּ בְּ״לֹא אֵיטִיב״; הָכָא מִי אִיתֵיהּ בְּ״לֹא אֲקַיֵּים״?!
human_translation: And the Rabbis there, there is I will not do good. Here, is there I will not perform
llm_translation: The Sages - there, it has "without being good"; here, does it have "without fulfilling"?!

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל כִּכָּר זוֹ״; ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכְלֶנָּה״; ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכְלֶנָּה״; וַאֲכָלָהּ – אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת.
human_translation: oath I will not eat this loaf, oath I will not eat it, oath I will not eat it, and he ate it, he is liable only once.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "An oath not to eat this loaf," "An oath not to eat it," "An oath not to eat it," and he ate it - he is only liable for one.

hebrew_text: זוֹ הִיא שְׁבוּעַת בִּטּוּי – שֶׁחַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנָהּ מַכּוֹת, וְעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ קׇרְבָּן עוֹלֶה וְיוֹרֵד.
human_translation: This is an oath on an utterance, for which liable lashes for intentionally it, and for unwittingly it a sliding-scale offering.
llm_translation: This is the oath of testimony - that one is liable for intentional transgression with lashes, and for unintentional transgression with a burnt offering and a sin offering.

hebrew_text: שְׁבוּעַת שָׁוְא – חַיָּיבִין עַל זְדוֹנָהּ מַכּוֹת, וְעַל שִׁגְגָתָהּ פָּטוּר.
human_translation: an oath in vain, liable lashes when intentionally, and exempt when unwittingly.
llm_translation: Oath of falsehood - liable for intentional sin, and for unintentional sin exempt.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ לְמָה לִי לְמִיתְנֵי ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכְלֶנָּה״?
